A brief synopsis - maniac falls in love with schoolgirl, kills family, gets arrested, goes to jail, escapes from jail, goes looking for schoolgirl. Simple enough, and this is where the bulk of the film begins - Senior Prom Night, and the night Mr Maniac picks to ..uh.. woo Mrs Schoolgirl ..? Okay, so there's better and easier nights to pick, but this wouldn't do much for the films title.

The movie gets underway like any other average teen horror, predictable killings and cheap scares as the killer closes in on his prey, there's a small amount of underlying tension building throughout the first half, but it could have been done so much better if it wasn't ruined by the typical Hollywood rush job. But okay, its not a masterpiece. The second act for me is the best. I enjoyed the way the film introduced a Police Detective with evident intelligence, and as we soon learn the killers close on the tail of our schoolgirl heroine, the film reaches its best parts, and we're not just seeing the film almost purely from the viewpoint of the victim (like so many poor horrors), but seeing the whole situation for what it is. We're stepping back and saying 'Here We Are, This is Where We're At' and this for me was refreshing. The third act was predictably the big...let down. I take back the Police Detectives evident intelligence, you've let me down sir..some bad decisions on your half. Bit of an anticlimax ending also, but hey, what ya gonna do.

The acting? Good actually. No Oscars here, but there were hardly any cheesy lines, fake expressions or what not. Brittany Snow is good, and the supporting cast do what they can with the airtime they're given.

Overall, not a bad film. Probably better for me going in with low expectations, which may have heightened the experience. Its not a horror though, which some people may argue why it was bad. Come to this film expecting a thriller and you'll enjoy it more. There's no gore, not a lot of suspense and no creepy haunted house here. This is the straight to DVD kind of thriller.

Some people will moan about the predictable clichés (there were some) and the predictable plot (okay, the final act was predictable) but lets face it, its not going for any Film of the Year awards. Its good fun, just sit back, go in with no expectations and enjoy the ride. There are so many awful awful films out there with better ratings than 3.7, this isn't one of them.

Craig

review_title: Rated B, for B*$ch don't waste your time

review_detailed_main: If you are looking for a teen/thriller/slasher/over the top kind of film then this is it. If you expect anymore than you will be disappointed.

First, this is a review of the UNRATED version, which makes it even more of a shocking let down. Digressing to the fact that this is NOT a remake of the original, this one has a very thin premise, but that would be fine if the movie was good in executing a slasher film. The acting is fine so it's not a case of poor acting, it's a case of THIS IS SO EMPTY and DEVIOD of entertainment. It is missing almost all the content required (in at least a decent mix) of the elements needed to attain proper "Slasher" status.

1) I am not a fan of gore/torture porn so the kills OWULD be fine , but they were so quick and hinted at (Mostly facial expressions) that even a slasher nut like me who doesn't like crossing the line into ridiculous torture or gore couldn't fine the quick, blink and you'll miss them, kill shots.

2) The story, though extremely thin is fine for a slasher, but there's is so little of it delved into that it's basically just a commercial for "Why this all happening" without any character development at all. You feel little to nothing for any of the characters and have near ZERO fear of the villain.

3) there was ZERO T&A, (Remember, I own the UNRATED version) there was NO "boob" shot for the Straight men and Lesbians, and no Butt shots for the Straight women and Gay men to get that "slasher ummm giggle" (Whether you find that cheap or not is your own affair, it is still a HUGE ingredient in a good slasher film as long as both genders show a bit of T&A for the crowd to avoid accusations of exploitation of one gender which can be a problem in many films regarding only showing female nudity) This has ZERO, not even the unrated version.

4) the conclusion is abrupt and leaves you with very little satisfaction, and ZERO to look back on the film with a "Well at least there was this or that" to hold on to as a worthwhile memory for your time.

I'm am glad about only 1 thing, that I got this brand new Unrated version for just 3.99 on EBay and so cannot be mad about losing 20 bucks or something...lol I find it very hard to imagine what they "put back in" to call this the UNRATED version, I can only imagine how awful the PG-13 version must have been if this unrated version is suppose to have more...lmao Because there was NOTHING THERE. Save your 4-5 bucks you can buy this for, and pass on this film.

review_title: Not a remake, not original, just not a good movie!!! Period!!!

review_detailed_main:
Donna Keppel (Brittany Snow) returns home to find her obsessed former teacher Richard Fenton killing her family. He's put away in prison but she still has nightmares about him despite treatment from Dr. Crowe. Three years later, she's going to senior prom with boyfriend Bobby, best friends Lisa Hines and Claire. Then Detective Winn (Idris Elba) is told that Fenton had escaped from prison. He contacts Donna's new guardians Aunt Karen and Uncle Jack. Winn tries to find Donna but Fenton is already at the prom.

It's a lot of unscary jump scares. Everything is predictable. It is all paint-by-numbers horror. The kills are nothing special. It's not especially bloody. The killer isn't a mystery. The cops are really incompetent. It shouldn't be that hard to find a girl. Even in a world without cell phones, they could call the front desk. When they find the dead body, they should be rushing around. I know they don't want a panic but there's a killer on the loose. It's also not good for the tension of the movie. It just feels lifeless.

review_title: It's not a remake - but tried to capitalize on being one!
review_detailed_main:
Wow. That's all I can say. This movie is definitely NOT a remake of the 1980 original, even though every review and ad I read in the papers claimed it was. It's really nothing other than a badly clichéd 'horror' knock-off. I like the original. Yes, Jamie Lee Curtis is in it, but she's not even the main focus of that movie which many seem to have forgotten. Anyway, I digress...

This very typical, ordinary, plain and so-bad-and-cliché-you-can-say-what's-going-to-happen-before-it-does 'film' should have been direct-to-DVD, if even that. It's like a cable special that somehow made it to the screen. All of the actors are too old and not very likable/relatable. When they're offed, you could care less. It's crap masquerading under the Prom Night title.

review_title: I thought it was a good movie!
review_detailed_main: OK, so, first off, this movie was not nearly as bad as the critics or some people in general thought it was. I mean, sure it was predictable in parts and the killings with the knife got kind of old after a while, but it was still a good movie to watch without you being badly disappointed! Sure for some people who are expecting a grotesque slasher film with a lot "dirty" material and scenes that will scare you horrifically it will be a bad movie, but you can't expect that. It was just another good movie! It wasn't outstanding, it wasn't unbelievable, it wasn't horrible, it wasn't bad, it was good! Just be happy with it because it could have been A LOT WORSE!!! It also could have been better. But that doesn't mean it was bad! It wasn't really scary but it had it's moments! It was suspenseful and also a little disturbing! There was also a make out scene for some people who like that ;-) I can see how the critics wouldn't like it and I can also see how some people in general wouldn't like it, but there are also some people out there that will find it great or good! Teens - some will like it some will not. People that are in their 20's - some will like it, some will not. 30's and over - they are most likely to like it less than other people, but some of them still will like it! My mom did and she is 41! Overall, it's just a good movie and for people who are expecting a grotesque slasher film with a lot "dirty" material and scenes that will scare you horrifically it will be a bad movie as I said above! So don't expect that! Expect what I told you :-)

review_title: Rated PG-13 made for TEENS! Stop complaining!
review_detailed_main: This movie gets a bad rep for all the wrong reasons! It's probably due to the Title "Prom Night" which was famously named after the original in 1980. So people usually compare the movies and assume it's suppose to be the same horror/slasher storyline. This "remake" was suppose to be a different plot with honestly its only resemblance to the original is sharing the same title. If you look at the movie through a teens lenses and come to the concussion that this PG-13 movie was a THRILLER not a "slasher" and made for teens. Then I think you'd enjoy this movie just like I did when I watched it for the first time in theaters at 16!

review_title: A night you'll want to forget in a hurry.
review_detailed_main:
Why Hollywood feels the need to remake movies that were so brilliant their prime (The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, The Hills Have Eyes) but is it considerably worse why Hollywood feels the need to remake those horror films that weren't brilliant to start with (Prom Night, The Amityville Horror) Much like their originals these remakes fail in creating atmosphere, character or any genuine scares at all. Prom night is so flat and uninteresting its hard to watch, but for all the wrong reasons.

It's a poorly acted, massively uninteresting and ultimately dull excursion that fails at everything its designed to do. It's clear Hollywood Horror is dead. Even The likes of The Hills Have Eyes and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre managed to ruin their franchises in style with buckets of blood and a decent plot. Prom night is virtually bloodless and I'm not even going to mention how bad the plot is. Its inability to seal the killers identify makes this the least suspenseful horror movie since erm... the original.

One of the most notorious slasher films of the 1980s returns to terrorize filmgoers with this remake that proves just how horrifying high school dances can truly be. Donna Keppel (Brittany Snow) has survived a terrible tragedy, but now the time has come to leave the past behind and celebrate her senior prom in style.

When the big night finally arrives, Donna and her best friends prepare to enjoy their last big high-school blowout by living it up and partying till dawn. But while Donna is willing to look past her nightmares and into a brighter future, the man she thought she had escaped forever has returned for one last dance. An obsessed killer is on the loose, and he'll slay anyone who attempts to prevent him from reaching his one and only Donna.

Who will survive to see graduation day, and what will Donna do when she's forced to confront her greatest fear? Scott Porter, Jessica Stroup, and Dana Davis co-star in the slasher remake that will have tuxedo-clad teens everywhere nervously looking over their shoulders as they file out onto the dance floor. A plot that will probably put you off going to see this. Witch if you ask me is a good thing.

Without much to work with, McCormick gamely tries to milk tension out of the most banal of situations. At one point, a girl backs into a floor lamp (a lamp!) and McCormick tries to pump it up into a jump-scare moment. Desperate times really do call for desperate measures. There haven't been this many shots of closets since the last IKEA catalogue.

In the era of The Hills, My Super Sweet 16 and To Catch a Predator, there probably is a freaky, scary movie to be mined from the commoditisation of glamour and society's creepy obsession with youthful beauty. This is not that movie.

My final verdict? Avoid at all cost. Nobody will like Prom Night, it's even a disappointment to thoses who usually enjoy hack-job remakes. Considering its absolute lack of blood or frights. A night you'll be in a hurry to forget.

review_title: Chewed Too Much Than It Could Swallow
review_detailed_main:
Donna's senior prom is supposed to be the best night of her life. After surviving a horrible tragedy, she has finally moved on and is enjoying her last year of high school. Surrounded by her best friends, she should be safe from the horrors of her past. But when the night turns deadly, there is only one person who could be responsible... a man she thought was gone forever.

Now, Donna and her friends must find a way to escape the sadistic rampage of an obsessed killer, and survive a night "to die for." It is very stupid i can't believe i wasted $7.50 for this obvious waste of time and space. Prom Night 2/10

review_title: Boring, dull, tedious, clichéd, rubbish... and that's the good points!(plot details given)
I want to kick the writers in the nuts for wasting two hours of my time
review_detailed_main:
Wow, I am almost speechless that this piece of garbage ever saw the inside of a movie theater. It amazes me that people took the time out to write this. I think the writers took clichés from a whole bunch of old horror movies and made what I will call "The Mother Of All Cliché Movies" a.k.a Prom Night. From beginning to end you will wonder to yourself why someone would do something so far logical. If it were just far fetched it would have been OK. The problem is it's far fetched and ridiculous at the same time. The worst problem with this movie is that by the time you realize who bad the movie is, your past the point of no return.. you know, when you invested too much time in it to turn it off as that would be a waste of your time. DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME WITH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!

P.S. The special effects guy from this movie should not only not be allowed to work on another film, he shouldn't even be allowed near a Heinz ketchup bottle again! Who gets stabbed multiple times and only has a few red spots on their white shirt? Has the guy ever seen an episode of Forensic Files?

review_title: A terrible waste of a cinema trip!
review_detailed_main:
If I could give this film a real rating, it would likely be in the minus numbers. While I respect the fact that somebody has to keep making these terrible "horror" films, seriously, people, buying a ticket for this film is a waste of money you could be spending on something far more worth your time.

Despite it being a horror film, there is nothing scary about it, unless the idea of seeing how many horror cliché's you can fit in one movie scares you. If the rating had been higher, it probably would have made for a better film in the long run.

Whoever made this version of "Prom Night", you screwed up. The actors could probably have done a decent job if it weren't for the questionable scripting. This was a terrible waste of a cinema trip. I'd sooner go and see "One Missed Call" again, at least that had some plot.

review_title: The Italian Title Is Right: Let The End Begin!

review_detailed_main: I can't believe I actually sat through this thing. This might be the worst movie I've ever seen. Whoever chose this movie to be funded or produced should be shot. On top of the incredibly lame production value, predictable doesn't even begin to describe the plot. It looks like this might have been shot in Canada. I couldn't watch the credits because I was busy looking for a knife to slash my wrists. Perhaps the producers would have been better served focusing on developing a screenplay before they send it up north to get ruined by weak production value. Shame on everyone involved. Save yourself two hours, go walk in a lightning storm, and you'll still feel like you wasted less time. Producers try finding some better material or go back to business school and finish your MBA!

The Prom Night remake is really not a retelling of the 1980 horror classic. The story is completely different from that one or any of the sequels that followed. In this film, a young girl Donna (Brittany Snow) watched in horror as a man brutally killed her entire family. Much time has past and her prom night is fast approaching. She has been living with her aunt and uncle since the nightmarish incident. The man who killed her family is revealed as her school teacher (Richard Fenton) who developed a very unhealthy infatuation with her to the point he would kill to be with her. Of course as prom night hits, we see that the psychopath has escaped from the asylum he was in. The prom is held at a gorgeous hotel, and our four main teenage characters rent a room on the third floor. Of course the killer follows them to the hotel and up to their floor. A few murders take place throughout the middle part of the film. None of the murders are very gory, but there is a certain brutality with the way in which he kills them. There is one chase scene in the hotel, which I guess pays homage to the 1980 film where Wendy gets chased throughout the school for 10-15 minutes. Donna finds out that he has escaped and is in the hotel. This all leads up to an ending that leaves you sort of wanting more.

That's how this movie came across to me. It constantly left me wanting more. The murders were very quickly done and had little suspense to it. It just felt like the makers of the movie wanted to rush through a lot of good stuff that makes horror fun, and just skip to the story and the ambiance of the prom night dance scene. The reason the original prom night worked was because of the suspense with the killer's identity. It kept you on the edge of your seat waiting to find out who was doing the killing and why. In this one, we know from the start who it is and why. And the motive of the killer is very weak in my opinion. There are some good parts within the hotel corridors, especially the chase scene involving Lisa (Dana Davis) and the crazed maniac. The acting for the most part is very good. Brittany Snow and Dana Davis were believable and Johnathan Schaech who plays the killer is pretty creepy.

Prom Night (2008) is sort of the perfect horror film for a person who cannot handle real scary movies. It milks out all possible gore and suspense and leaves you with some jump scares and a few bloodless kills. It is a decent watch for a modern day horror film, but the 1980 version is much better.

6/10

review_title: Best bad movie of the year.
review_detailed_main:
OK, so Prom Night was the most popular movie at my school a few weeks back, all my friends had seen it, some liked it, some hated it. So my friend was willing to see it again with me, so I could see if I liked it. We were the first ones in that room, because everybody else was seeing Iron Man. There were only three other people who showed up after us and boy, did we have fun.

It was flat out terrible, completely predictable and funny every time we were supposed to be scared. For example, in one scene, one of the protagonist's friends is running away from the killer, and the elevator won't show up in time, so the girl decides to run down the stairs with her high heels on, she breaks one of the heels, takes the shoe off, and continues running down the stairs with one high heel shoe on and the other off. Pardon me, but if the girls are really that dumb, then they almost deserve to die.

This movie is so dumb, that I was whispering to my friend what I thought was going to happen, and nine out of ten times, that's exactly what happened. Now if you like classic horror movies and want to be scared, you will be disappointed, but if you want to see one of the years biggest laugh riots, you'll be pleasantly entertained.

review_title: I thought this would be a terrible movie but i was wrong and i liked it.
review_detailed_main:
When Donna (Brittany Snow) was 14 years old, she witness her mother and family getting killed by her crazed ex-science teacher Richard Fenton (Johnathon Schaech). Which Fenton had a dangerous crush on his student. Three years has passed, Donna is trying to move on with her life. Especially her and friends are going to their senior's Prom Night together for the last time before College. But Fenton actually escaped from the mental hospital to be with Donna and he kills people, who gets in his way to get to Donna.

Directed by Nelson McCormick (Who's an pro directing T.V. Episodes like "E/R", "Nip/Tuck" and "NYPD Blue") made an entertaining teen slasher movie with the right moments of suspense and terror. Schaech does an good job playing the crazy serial murderer in the movie. Although i am not a big fan of actress:Snow, she does an pretty good job in the feature. Idris Elba has an scene-stealing supporting performance as Detective Winn. The cast are likable as well like Jessica Stroup (The lead actress from "The Hills Have Eyes 2"), Dana Davis, Collins Pennie, Scott Porter, Linden Ashby, Mary Mara and others.

DVD from "Prom Night" is actually the Unrated Version, it includes one minute of additional footage (Mostly violence are added back in this version). DVD has an solid anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer and an strong Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD has an entertaining commentary track by the filmmakers, actors:Snow and Schaech. DVD also includes Deleted Scenes with optional commentary by the filmmaker, same goes from the Alternate Ending, Featurettes and Bloopers. This is not a remake of the infamous Canadian film of the same-name, who was starring Jamie Lee Curtis and Leslie Nielsen. Although there's one scene in the new Prom Night that reminds me of the original. Slasher fans will find some enjoyment in this thriller and don't listen to the critics in this one, just watch and enjoy it. Joshua Leonard from "The Blair Witch Project" fame has an amusing cameo as one of Fenton's victims. Written by B-Movie Scripter:J.S. Cardone (Alien Hunter, The Covenant, The Forsaken). Super 35. (*** ½/*****).

review_title: Not as funny as Supherhero Movie, but just as funny as Superbad, which is what this movie is: Super Bad.
review_detailed_main:
It's a bad remake of a bad seventies slasher movie starring Jamie Lee Curtis.

If you like fake scares--Oh, it's just her aunt, it's just some pigeons that have no earthly reason to be there, and my favorite, OH! It's just a lamp--this is your movie.

There are really only two surprises in the entire film. It's typical bad slasher movie. In its day, the original Prom Night was just a bad attempt to recreate the John Carpenter Halloween-magic. 25 years later, some are still trying to match it......and failing.

And the PG-13 rating doesn't help....we don't even get to see any old-fashioned sex and gore--usually in that order.

Though the performances were good, the characters and the storyline, different from the original, were just not engaging. By the end I didn't care so much about who lived and who died as much as I cared about when it would be over.

Skip Prom Night. If you want scared, go see The Ruins. I found myself laughing more than screaming. OK, that's a lie......I didn't scream I give it a C for "Who Crapped This Thing?"

The original one looked like a TV movie. This one, a b-movie. There's improvement I guess. But the thing that ruined everything was the rating. PG 13, meaning no real thrills, nothing too scary or bloody. Let alone creepy. Just your average slow paced horror/thriller, with a couple of characters interactions (to make you feel for them, when they eventually get killed off) before each (off screen) executions. With a blade, so nothing too graphical is shown. What a boring way to envision a slasher. The main appeal remains in the casting, filled with popular TV actors that used to have their own popular shows, to draw in audience. So it has that kind of nostalgia feel now. And the popularity factor when it was released on Summer (?) 2008. Unfortunately, the tension build up is almost inexistant, so the young audience won't be too « traumatized ». That it is like grasping at straws, to find the movie thrilling. At least the actors in this « version » look like real teenagers, not 30 somethings... Good enough, when you know what to expect, but that's it.

review_title: Oh. My God. You totally scared me!
review_detailed_main:
The only thing worse that Hollywood stealing foreign films and remaking them with dumb cable stars (WB, Fox, CW), is Hollywood stealing ideas from slasher films and presenting the same so-called stars in a film that has to be the worst film of the year.

Yes, I know, it didn't get a Razzie nomination, but that was only because the category of Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-Off or Sequel had some many more deserving nominees.

What really galls me is the Unrated version of this film. Adult content, according to raters, but, at the same time, considered appropriate for 15+. Since when is 15 the age of consent. Are 15-year-olds adults? Can they consent to sex, buy booze or smokes? You know the answer. This is commercial ripoff in the highest form.

Now there were supposed to be 13 murders in this film. I saw five. I must have slept through the rest of them. The five I saw - not one drop of blood. Language? "Bitch" was the strongest word I heard.

Bottom line. A five years old can watch this and the only scare they are going to get is some teen girl screaming. Pathetic.

review_title: Prom Night (2008) - Neither Bad or Good
Silly, but semi-watchable pre-teen slash fest!
review_detailed_main:
Screen Gems' Prom Night, the latest in a long, seemingly endless line of pre-teen geared PG-13 horror films, proves that Hollywood still has a long way to go before they realize how a good horror film works. Prom Night promises a lot, but leaves the viewer feeling stood up and alone by the end of the movie.

A remake of the popular 1980 Jamie Lee Curtis slasher vehicle, Prom Night discards the original's more interesting plot and opts for a more obvious, silly, and TV movie storyline, centering around innocent teenage Donna (Brittany Snow) and the older male teacher who is obsessed with her. Needless to say, the new story could have truly gone somewhere and it's a shame that it ends up feeling more like a typical Lifetime movie event rather than a scary or suspenseful thriller.

The young cast manage to give pretty decent performances, but they have very, very little to work with. Dana Davis as Donna's best friend, Lisa, is especially likable.

The film's condescending PG-13 level shocks and scares are pretty dull and bland, but the film does have a nice pace to keep things rolling smoothly, which is one thing that you can't say for other watered down pre-teen efforts like Boogeyman and When A Stranger Calls.

Fans of the original might want to consider this new film as more of an unofficial sequel in the Prom Night series. Eiher way, no matter how you think of it, remake or sequel, it's a disappointing, scare less affair, with a lots of potential, but little pizazz.

Donnas senior prom is supposed to be the best night of her life, one of magic, beauty, and love. Surrounded by her best friends, she should be safe from the horrors of her past. But when the night turns from magic to murder there is only one man who could be responsible, the man she thought was gone forever. Now, Donna and her friends must find a way to escape the sadistic rampage of an obsessed killer, and survive their Prom Night.

Forget about what you've heard about this movie. Forget about the critics panning this film. Forget all of that. This movie isn't bad as people said it was. When horror fans think "slasher" and "PG-13," they assume it won't mix well, because the base formula for a slasher is blood, guts, and gore. Unfortunately, since this movie is PG-13, it has barely any of that.

Now here comes the catcher: This movie relies more on suspense, a brooding, ominous atmosphere, and sound effects to scare the audience, which, more or less works. The bad thing is that there are some clichés. The good thing is it's different from everyday slashers. Like I said, barely any blood is spilled in here.

If you don't like the sound of that, well, skip this movie. It isn't for you. Yes, the clichés are still there, like some big "WTF" moments pop out in the middle of some scenes because of some characters' stupid moves. Other "WTF" moments, in my opinion, is the unusually high body count, which is ten or more. I found some kills very unnecessary but I guess it was to please the gore hounds out there, which obviously didn't work. I was also disappointed in the end.

Apart from those flaws, the film stands up pretty well. I appreciate that the film was trying to do something new. I love the use of sound here, and if you know me, I usually don't praise horror movies for their sound effects. The use of sound makes this movie more suspenseful and gives it a more dark tone. I also love the way the kills were shot. It was different and unique.

I also liked the fact the filmmakers decided to show the killer's face within five minutes into the movie. Judging from the trailer, you would think they'll show it in the end but you're wrong. The performances were good. I also felt some sympathy for the characters, which is also another high point in the movie.

Overall, the way this film was shot, the use of sound, and some other magical elements in this film, like the young, unknown cast, gave the film some life. The film is not perfect in any way but I liked that it was trying to be different, and although it may have failed with many viewers, whom weren't likely the target demographic in the first place, I appreciated that.

This film is full of cliches, I knew what was about to be happening, who was going to be dying, etc.

The other thing that personally annoyed me was the representation of the film, as a reboot of the 1980 original of the same name. To be honest I didn't liked the original, I think it is bad for other reasons. This "remake" has nothing to do with the original. It's a completely different film, since does not contain any similar elements from its prior. The story line is also completely different. I personally like obsession themed films, so this is the only one bonus in this one.

Another thing that I didn't like is the protagonist. She never convinced me. I didn't liked her acting skills. I would prefer someone else to take the part. Maybe it would be better (?), I don't know... then the killer. We know from the beginning of the film who the villain is, so automatically this film does not make the viewer to be concerned, to trying to guess who is the killer. Besides, he wasn't either convincing as a killer.

The killer was so obvious, that if you would just stare at him, you knew that he's a bad person. But no! No one actually understood a thing. He was somehow "invisible"! Plus, it wasn't scary or even suspenseful at all...

So, I fully understand the reason of why this film is hated. To me is a completely stand alone, since it has no connection with its prior. In my opinion, when it is decided to be made a remake, of course they should do this different, because (personally) I don't want to watch the same film, but the story line it could be kinda similar, and of course the most memorable elements of the original (if not all of course) they have to get into the film, so I (we) can understand the reference from the authentic movie.

Not recommended.

Looking at this movie and what it represents as a whole, it is in some ways supposed to be a remake.

It does reference a number of horror films that have come and gone, but it especially seems to take off from the original Halloween film that featured Michael Myers. In this day in age, it would be hard to have total originality in a horror film because of the history of horror movies.

This movie strays from the plot of the original Prom Night, which featured Halloween star, Jamie Lee Curtis. Brittany Snow has made her mark in Hollywood, but on a different scale of acting.

The film follows all the criteria that is needed for a B horror movie, however you are sensitized by stronger characterizations of having more than one dimension to the others on the screen. For the setting the plot has, it is necessary and may even suggests that the film could have been longer to further develop Donna and her friends.

Overall, it isn't the worst horror movie, or the best. Films like these quite often are underrated on IMDb and don't get the attention that they are screaming for. If you like a good thrill, take my advice and see it.

Rating: 2 out of 5

Genre: Horror, Slasher, Thriller, Remake, PG-13 Horror

Director: Nelson McCormick

Stars: Brittany Snow, Scott Porter, Jessica Stroup, Dana Davis, Collins Pennie, Kelly Blatz, James Ransone, Brianna Davis, Kellan Lutz, Mary Mara, Johnathon Schaech

Synopsis: Donna (Snow) is just now starting to rebuild her life after her parents and brother were brutally slaughtered by an obsessed former teacher. Now on the day of her senior prom he escapes from the asylum and the real fear begins.

Thoughts: Next up on the remake chopping block is this pretty bland slasher. Truth be told I was never really fond of the 1980 original that starred scream queen Jamie Lee Curtis so I thought a remake couldn't hurt this one. I did like the remake a bit more. There is really no suspense since it's revealed right off the bat who the killer is. There isn't a whole lot of grue in either the PG-13 rated version or the unrated for that matter. The screenplay goes through the motions and clichés and never really does much to engage the watcher. The photography is fine since the main bulk of the action takes place at the hotel. The sound design picks up a little slack by making the kills sound much worse than they were. The cast is pretty, faceless and chock full of the teen drama types.

In Conclusion: 'Prom Night' is a bland remake that still manages to better the original, barely. Good for teenagers and snore inducing for adults.

Three years ago, Donna(Brittany Snow) was forced to watch her former teacher Richard Fenton(Jonathan Schaech), who was obsessed with the girl, kill her entire family. Fenton was put away and Donna had to go into therapy. Now it's Donna's last year of high school and she's getting ready for the senior prom. But Fenton's escaped from jail and he tracks her to the prom. Det. Winn(Idris Elba), the man who put away the psycho those years ago, desperately tries to stop him before he finishes what he once started.

Now I know there are crappy horror remakes like House of Wax and One Missed Call, but this one takes the cake. For the positives, it's incredibly short. But that's about it. The acting is pathetic, with wooden performances all around. The scares are weak too.This is supposed to be a horror film. You need the occasional pop-ups. But this ruins any of those chances, like Fenton slowly appearing out of the darkness to the point where you can see him clearly and then attempting to scare the wits out of you, but that slow movement has already killed that off.

Overall I give it a 1 out of 10(I wish there was a zero stars option). This is definitely a night I WOULD want to forget.

review_title: One Of The Best Teenage Slasher Movies Ever
review_detailed_main:
Besides all the girls in the theater screaming their heads off every two minutes, it was an amazing movie. Johnathon Schaech gave an amazing performance as Richard Fenton. Hes the perfect guy to play the role of a creepy killer. The amount off effort that Brittany Snow put into her role as Donna Keppel. Brittany Snow is nicely cast as the vulnerable Donna whose nightmares give us an early opportunity to understand the circumstances in which her parents and brother were murdered. There's fun and laughter as Donna and her two best friends prepare for their big night with cool frocks, hairdos, stretch limos, attentive boyfriends and high expectations. From the start, director Nelson McCormick injects jabs of uncertainty into the proceedings. Tension builds as we, the audience, know more than the characters. There's the clanging of the hangers in the closet, the creaking door, a disappearing face in the mirror, a figure in the doorway. There are screams, a splash of bright red blood and shadows in the darkness. Predictably, the first victim is someone we don't know. The next is someone we care little about. Then the killings step up a notch.

McCormick toys with the tone, flitting back and forth to the light and gleam of the ultra modern LA Club-style prom for relief, after each killing. There's a contrast of obsessions - between Johnathon Schaech's darkly broody killer, Richard Fenton, and Idris Elba's Detective Winn. Fenton obsesses about Donna as something he must possess, while the detective is determined to stop Fenton at all costs. Schaech, with his angular features and disturbing stare is a convincing villain while excellent editing by Australian Jason Ballantine (Wolf Creek, Rogue) keeps the story moving as it neatly unsettles our equilibrium. Unashamedly catering for its target market, Prom Night delivers pretty much what you expect with enough scares to satisfy but not to keep you awake till the wee small hours. If your into suspenseful horror movies or just wanna see a good movie, i strongly suggest you go see this movie as soon as possible. and i know this review isn't detailed about the movie, but thats because i don't want to spoil it for you. and trust me, you wont want to miss this movie.

review_title: A ridiculous PG-13'd slasher flick that doesn't even try much of anything
A promising premise, not directed well.
A Disappointing And Unrealistic Series of Events
review_detailed_main:
Prom Night (2008) is a modern re-make of a 1980s film of the same name. However, Prom Night fails to capture the imagination, tell a realistic stalker story, and develop characters despite massive emotional trauma being present.

The entire premise of Prom Night revolves around a series of unrealistic mistakes from a wide range of people. The narrative takes you out of the story once you realize the entire scenario is highly unlikely.

The film could have been good if it touched on the issues Donna Keppel (Brittany Snow) has to deal with after first encountering her stalker. The one good point about the film is the acting is solid and shows what type of film Prom Night could have been with a much better script.

Idris Elba and Ming-Na Wen are in the film, but neither is used up to their abilities due to the flat script.

True Score: 4.9.

review_title: Not a classic but its a non- brainer.
review_detailed_main: With the original coming from the legendary era of horror the 80,s. The re-make was obviously not gonna reach the expectations of true horror fans but for the teenagers of today like myself it's a no- brainer. To put simply it gives you the eye candy ; Brittany Snow , the simple plot , the stereotypical characters and the obvious ending. Despite all the bad reviews about this film however it did make a lot in the box office just showing that the movie watching generation like the " Non - Brainer Films ". If your in the mood to sit back with your teenage Bf / Gf and make out during it without worrying your going to be behind then this is the film for you. If your a true horror fan steer clear this film otherwise i'll be expecting a bad review from you.

review_title: Take it for what it is!
review_detailed_main:
So, before I begin, one thing I really need to stress.

To all the bad reviews on here with "high hopes" or "expectations" ....... The movie is called Prom Night, what did you expect?

Yes, the movie is unbelievably cliché, yes, the characters are your typical teen/horror movie characters, but again -- the movie is called Prom Night.

I'm tired of listening to folk whine about how upset they are that movies like Prom Night turn out with the aspects I stated above.

Your teen slasher is always |ALWAYS| going to turn out like this. Sure, some will be better than others, but when it comes down to it, they're all the same. Centers on the girl, her friends get slaughtered because the "stalker" wants to get close to her, the cops try save her, she almost dies, they shoot, stab or set him on fire -- the end.

Right? Yes.

Now, Prom Night wasn't the best I've seen from this genre, not even half-way, but, there were a good few scares here and there that I will admit to gasping too.

The main problem with this movie was, the usual story (I stated above^) was too obvious, even for a movie like this. She looks in the mirror, he's there, she turns - he's not there. The friend has an argument with her boyfriend, she goes up-stairs to chill = killing time.

The biggest thing that got to me was the choices these teens made, for instance.

The Prom is held at a well-off, beautiful hotel. Towards the end of the movie, the cops take over and tell everyone to leave - so you leave, right? No.

The automated voice is talking over the loud speaker: "Emergency, please leave the building" (repeated over and over). So, what does the girl do?

"Oh I forgot my moms shawl, it's up-stairs" of course, because that's the first thing you worry about, naturally.

There are about one hundred of those "shawl" moments in this movie that it just gets you thinking, it's now 2008, can't they come up with anything better?

Now, I'm not gonna take a pop at the actors, because their acting was good, but with this material, there's only so much you can do.

Go into this movie the way I went into it. I expected the expected, and I was right.

Don't go into a slasher movie titled, "Prom Night" thinking you're gonna get a stunning piece of film.

It's just not common logic.

This movie is great. Don't let the bad reviews deter you away because this movie was entertaining, fun and enjoyable. Better than the other prom night with Jamie. Yeah i know some of you hate me now cuz of that but its the truth. The chase scene was so awesome and very upset by the outcome but it was so good and every time i see it I'm always rooting for the best,silly me lol. But its so good and its not a horror flick, its a thriller more. I was never bored and always like wow, i can never get tired of seeing it. Its a fun time so watch it, don't let the negative reviews fool you, just know thats its a thriller and not a slasher flick and you'll be fine, promise.

Prom Night is a paint-by-numbers slasher movie. There's nothing really new or creative about this flick, other than the fact that it's PG-13. The predictable plot glides along a well-worn trail of blood, with a killer who seems to be superhuman in the way he's able to slice and dice his victims without detection. I don't get all the hate towards this horror movie, though. If you're a fan of the slasher genre, it's cut from the same cloth.

review_title: A Lot Better Than The Bad Reviews State
It's a horror that this is considered horror
review_detailed_main:
I absolutely hate PG-13 suspense/horror films because it limits what they can do. Mostly so it caters to the younger crowd. The only acception was Disturbia. Anyway, what's a good thing to say about this movie? It's short, but feels like 2 hours. Not suspenseful, not scary, and a crappy script. It's so sloppy, like they made it overnight or assigned a middle schooler to write it.

Basically, a teenager was stalked by a psycho teacher and he killed her family. He was sent away, and he broke out 3 years later on her senior prom and attacks the place. The killer is not mysterious or creepy, just a Javier Bardem in No Country For Old Men expression-less looking guy with a pocket knife....very scary. (sarcasm)

Don't waste your time or money on this atrocity, I wish I hadn't.

I think it was an overrated PG-13 crap! At least BRITTANY SNOW's performance was good and some others like IDRIS ELBA were good too, but some others teens in the prom like the leads friends were not that convincing. The killer was so dumb and looked so stupid too. The deaths were stupid, boring and completely unoriginals. The movie was very boring too and very overrated. It wasn't suspenseful at all, i almost fall asleep. Its another bad PG-13 remake, its really a dreadful movie IMO. The ending was so stupid and the climax was very rushed and boring. The movie is pretty slow too. Overall the only good thing about this crap fest is maybe BRITTANY SNOW i think she gave a good performance and IDRIS ELBA too, but besides that it was a completely dreadful movie and horrible remake. Well thats just my opinion. i gave it a 2/10.

Seriously guys this films sucked so much I left from a cinema for the 1st time in my life :( The story was boring and predictable, I didn't c the end but hell I have a rough idea of how it went down. The killer just seemed to kill people for no reason, managed to teleport dead bodies around rooms and magically move across a room without one of the main characters standing in the same room noticing?? The main characters are just annoying and I ended up not caring if they died and wishign some would get killed quicker because they annoyed me so much. The black girl only ever moaned about becoming the prom queen or slagging off her opponent, her boy friend just took pictures the whole time. The main character and her boyfriend just moaned about how they would not see each other again and how "real" their relationship was.

The killer never managed to kill anyone well not that I seen anyways, the camera just suddenly found another object in the room more interesting than one of the main characters getting killed and suddenly when we next see them they are dead. Another thing I noticed was that this killer wasn't scary, creepy or weird at all just that he wanted to screw some chick really bad.

There was no suspense or surprise at all when characters were about to die it was all predictable and very very boring. There was a cool slow down camera effect when the guy got killed when he jumped out of the wardrobe. This was actually the only memorable part of this movie to be honest DON'T GO AND SEE THIS< ITS A WASTE OF MONEY AND YOUR TIME

review_title: Watching this is like watching a non-contact boxing match on Pay per view.
review_detailed_main:
This has to be the blandest, most pointless "slasher" film I have ever seen. It takes all that is good about the genre and discards it just making do with tired old clichés and paper thin characters. I guess in theory the actual premise behind the story held water but it is used only as a device to explain the story instead of being integral to it. However the worst is yet to come, this SLASHER film is PG-13. Somebody, somewhere must understand the logic behind such a decision but for the life of me I can't. No sex, no gore, no bad language, no nudity. This is what you would get if Mary Whitehouse made a Slasher Flick.

Watching this is like watching a non-contact boxing match on Pay per view. It makes no sense what so ever.

No spoilers in this review! I dont know why everyone is saying it's bad i think it's really good! The suspense is there and there were so many plot twists. No, you can't really see people being killed or anything but I personally think it's really good. Worth watching! Will definitely be rewatching soon it's really good. --- I'm just going to keep typing because it won't let me submit until i have a certain amount of characters lol. So how is everyone's day? Mine is doing fine I'm planning on watching some more movies on Netflix I don't know which ones yet I want to watch some more horror ones.

No, this was not a GREAT movie, but it was still entertaining. It is your typical slasher flick and a relatively clean one, not too much gore. But unless you literally want blood and guts AND a Best Picture, it's still fun to watch. Why people expect this genre of film to be up there with the greatest movies of all time, is beyond me. They never will be. Ever. If you take this movie for what it is, and know that you'll be able to guess when most of the characters who die, die - then you'll probably enjoy it. If not, then this movie is not for you apparently.

review_title: Funnier than your average comedy, not in a good way
review_detailed_main:
Prom Night is the sort of horror movie you go into expecting nothing more than a cheap scare, sure in the long run it's likely to be forgettable, but so long as it makes you jump, gives you a laugh and lets you leave the cinema feeling entertained. Prom Night is your average slasher really, no big creepy set piece, nothing really out of the horror movie cliché, its just a piece of average horror junk. Its a shame then that its also a poorly made, acted, and delivered piece of horror junk that not only fails to entertain you, it fails to even slightly chill the bone, it fails to even make you jump! I'd have accepted this a tiny bit more if there was at least some gore to make the movie a tad more interesting, the gore is beyond tame, how this got a 15 is completely beyond me. Adding insult to injury the movie is also stupidly boring, its the same scene pretty much repeated over and over again, its only in the last half hour we get a tiny bit of change, and yet that features so many stupidly pointless scenes its hard to wonder what the hell the point in the movie is. Oh and did I mentioned its funny, stupidly funny. Hell I was crying with laughter in one bit, its a shame its completely unintentional, and the bit I am on about is a bit when a man gets killed. The stupidly poor reaction just sent me into hysterics. Prom Night is a thriller basically devoid of any thrills, the only reason it actually gets a 2 is because of the fact I laughed in it, and I think my brain has numbed the experience making me forget it almost instantly.

So onto the acting, or well the cardboard cut-outs. First there is Brittany Snow, who I noticed had a distractingly hairy face, anyway she was stupidly poor. Her acting experience ranging from startled expression to make random crying noises via trying not to scream. The opening sequence with her is just ridiculous, and one of the final scenes, which conveniently enough is repeated (yes the scene is literally a copy scene for scene) just shows you've had enough of the actress. The actual killer himself, played by Johnathon Schaech just has little to do. The biggest failure with the character is that we see him too often, he's just not scary as we know exactly where he is in every scene. The acting itself is tolerable, but then again he doesn't have to do much but look evil and stab people. Dana Davis (of Heroes fame) is just about tolerable, although once again she has little to do. She features in the best scene in the movie (trust me that isn't a compliment) as well as the very worst scene (random pigeons, good god). The rest of the cast really are that pointless/forgettable. Essentially they're there just to die, or go through the whole prom motions, or try and catch a killer, they're basically living breathing stereotypes running round.

So that gets me onto the horror side of the movie, or the extreme lack of it. As I have previously mentioned the movie fails because we see the killer to often. Its just so annoying. Scenes that start to become tense are ruined because we just see the killer calmly walk in, scenes that look like they may make you jump abruptly end when we see the killer just standing somewhere in a corner. Tense chase scenes are ruined by stupid random damned pigeons appearing out of nowhere! As you can imagine I really disliked the pigeon sequence. The film being unintentionally funny just stomps the final nail in the coffin really, the porter death scene is something that I want to see again just for a laugh really. The poor dialogue is just embarrassing, the script is once again embarrassing, and the ending so damned predictable you might as well have not bothered to even see the movie. The movie does admittedly improve as it goes on, the first forty minutes being almost unbearable. Once the killing starts you no longer want to slit your wrists, but you still have to cope with an incredible amount of stupidity.

Overall Prom Night is boring, stupid and just a lazy attempt at a horror movie. People who nearly die when watching the tamest horror movie could watch this, it just isn't scary, doesn't make you jump and doesn't even attempt to creep you out. Save your money, go rent the original Halloween if you want a good slasher.

review_title: Would've Been Lower If I didn't Laugh So Much
Anyone above 13 wouldn't enjoy it,funny how its rated pg-13
review_detailed_main: I feel like I need to warn you guys who haven't watch this,coz its so awful that I have to sit and watch Prom Night at the theater and wasted my 7 dollars.For a horror film,not being scary is one thing,but it has no plots ,and the characters are nothing special.The Hollywood high school,you call it.This is the first time I thought a movie is so BAD I have to warn you guys.Its really not worth it.Maybe the kids will enjoy it.But if you're 13 and above,promise you,you're not gonna be scared.Its not even funny.I find myself laughing when they kill people.How great this movie is? review_title: Come on people it's not that bad
review_detailed_main: I had skipped my lessons with my friends and walked into the cinema with an open mind for this movie, and despite all the * out of 10* comments I had read right here on this site just a while ago, I have to say that it really surprised me as well as my friends. People are saying things like its too predictable, or the directing and acting is horrendous...endless list. However its not unwatchable. At least it had my eyes opened for the entire screening. This movie is never meant to be an Oscar or box office robber, so just watch this movie like you are watching any Saturday night slasher flick, you won't be disappointed, or at least not so disappointed.

Oh dear...

I cannot even get angry about this movie, a remake of an 80s slasher that was a copy of Halloween anyway. This remake makes the tame slashers of the 1990s seem like snuff films!

I Know What You Did Last Summer has its critics but it is Hitchcock's Psycho compared to this shampoo commercial with screaming. Unfortunately it's inexplicably successful performance at the Box Office probably means more kindergarten safe 'horror' movies are being green-lit as we speak.

Bland performances, bland action ...bomb night!

review_title: So no Oscar material, big woof !
review_detailed_main:
An ordinary teen prom night slasher movie, for a Halloween or PJ party, or a sick day movie. Easily to watch, Idris Alba is doing a nice job besides being the hunk of the show.

So no deep, intellectual subtitled movie, just entertaining.

this adds nothing to the genre whatsoever.

This film has been made a thousand times before and shows no imagination, creativity or thought. The killing scenes are formulaic and entirely predictable and it is astounding studios will allow scripts, direction and acting like this.

The plot has more holes in it than a sieve and it is full of ridiculous moments where a character will say (not a spoiler) "there may be a mass murderer in the house but I am just going to the basement to replace that lightbulb that went out...."

Just astoundingly bad.

Dreadful.

Prom Night 2008, can not understand why all the bad comments. True it has very little to do with the original but that aside it is actually a really great film. Keep in mind that for PG-13 it still manages to be a horror film. I believe that was smart on the studios part since 13 and older would be the target audience for a movie that is about a prom whether it be "The Prom" or any high school dance. Britney Snow might have helped carry the movie, not sure, but still in the end it was up there with the rest. The movie has a sharp well polished look to it, and for many of the actors (not all of them) they are pretty likable and pass for any scary movie. By the way might be one of the sexiest serial killers since Michael Myers.

I have seen a lot of horror or thriller movies, but I am really surprised it has so many bad reviews. No it was not really a horror movie, but definitely not as bad as some other movies who have better reviews than this one.

No, it wasn't the best movie I have ever seen, but sometimes I really sat on the point of my seat. In my opinion it does not deserve this many bad reviews. I at least found it tensive to watch.

The storyline was good, the acting was great. Here and there I really was scared where the killer would be. Overall it was decent and not that bad.

This film just came out today in the UK. I thought it would be quite scary and a good night out, I mean its a 15 certificate. The only scary scenes are jumps, and there are so many. The killer is not scary. The victims are typical blonde Americans, all stupid. The cops are the worst I've ever seen. And the killer is not very good at killing either.

There is no comedy. Like the "Scream" films, it has comedy to support the up and down flow of the film so the scary bits are actually scary. This on the other hand is just drama and stupid teenage behaviour. It is funny when Tatum (Sidney's friend) gets trapped in a cat flap in "Scream" because its ironic. In "Prom Night" there is no comedy thus makes the tense bits (which happen a lot!) kind of dumb.

Overall: It did make me jump but I had to force myself to stay to the end. I can't believe people can make money from such bad entertainment.

This movie was so bad it actually physicaly hurt to watch.

This empty feeling after watching a movie should be illegal.

I actually feel like something was stolen from me and i will never get it back.

The amount of negative emotions after watching such a bad movie shuld be punishable by law.

Everything this people earned should be donated to special needs kids.

I know a guy that has no arms and is a bit slow and he is more creative than writers of this movie.

My little pony is scaryer than this "horror" movie.

Whatching paint dry would be a better use of my time.

Poking cows s**t is more interesting.

This was the worst experience I ever had in my life I would rather put a fork down my urethra and stick it in the working toaster.

review_title: Still a better movie than Rise of Skywalker
The main problem with this movie is that Steven King had nothing to do with it! Misery has its CRITICAL problems, too, but I wonder how people rate that?!
review_detailed_main: One problem for this movie in my opinion is the wild body placements: a loft or a car trunk on the outside?! It's possible that he could have gotten outside with a body--if he was clandestine enough; there is a network of stairs and police were busy guarding the prom and extra security was on Donna. Second entrances should be accounted for always(IT'S STANDARD OP FOR A ROACH OR RAT TO OPERATE WHERE PEOPLE WILL NOT LOOK AND A COP SHOULD THINK LIKE A CRIMINAL IN ORDER TO GET HIM), but sometimes they get overlooked. The loft's kind of iffy; they should have lost that, because that would mean getting blood on the carpet and for him to be a major bodybuilder: he didn't look like the type! Why go through the trouble of doing those 2 things when there's space under the bed. What hotel has one of those anyway?! The other one would be how the bodies kept conveniently popping up out of nowhere as the cops or Donna was passing by from the hiding space that the killer hid them WITHOUT REASON! I don't have problem with Donna's lack of emotion; she's lost her family and probably having post traumatic stress over this guy since; her emotions and emotional states are maybe beyond repair outside of divine intervention! Misery has bigger problem than this movie and I'm sure it got a pass; after all, Stephen King was behind that! Problems with Misery: 1. Him rolling around in a wheelchair as he did when Wilkes was probably going to be back within an hour or sooner! We have lived in a rural setting all my life and it took us about 20 minutes to go to the store at most no matter where we have lived at. So, he did not have all that time to go lazily through the house. 2. Then, he had stolen the pills; I accept that, but the knife?! And Paul didn't think repercussions were coming when his nurse had a medical chest full of things to do to him and could implement them whenever she wanted?! 3. Also, why would Paul have to write Misery back to life, if Annie burned his manuscript that never got published? THESE ARE 3 CRITICAL ERRORS THAT DOOM THAT MOVIE FROM BEING COMPLETED! To me, Prom Night has small errors compared to that classic!

review_title: Two different plots in one film. Could've worked... Results are poor overall.

review_detailed_main: Honestly, I don't know what a lot of people are talking about. The acting is pretty good to me and there are a decent amount of horror scenes that make you jump up. I guess there's not as much gore as I'd expect it but the little amount of gore that they had in this movie was very well done and it looked pretty real unlike some other horror movies these days that go way over the top with orange and pink blood. I love horror movies myself but I'm not picky if there's a little extra something in a horror movie. For instance, I think the problem with this movie is that it is claimed to be a horror movie but actually there are the same amount of drama scenes and action scenes. Not to mention that there seemed to be a lot more suspense scenes than horror scenes. Overall, I really enjoyed the movie and I really think that the acting on the actors starring in this movie was well done.

**SPOILERS** Even though the film uses the same title of the 1980 Jamie Lee Curtis horror flick its in no way a remake of that earlier slasher thriller.

In the movie we see pretty 18 year-old Donna Keppel played by Brittany-white as-Snow looking forward to attend her and her friends senior Prom Night at the famous Pacific Grand Hotel in downtown Bridgeport. Donna has been under psychiatric care and taking strong anti-psychotic drugs ever since her entire family was murdered by her English teacher Richard Fenton, Johnathon Schaech, three years ago. Fenton who had an obsessive attraction to the at that time 15 year-old Donna went berserk when she turned him down to be her lawfully or, in Donna not being at the age of consent, unlawfully wedded wife.

Unknown to both Donna and her Aunt Karen, Jessalyn Gilsig, and Uncle Jack, Linden Ashby, whom she's now living with Fenton has escaped from the loony bin, or mental institution, that he's been interned in. The murderously as well as revenge driven Fenton is now headed for the Grand Pacific to rekindle his strange and unnatural relationship with Donna. It's that relationship that ended so abruptly with his capture and conviction some three years ago.

The movie "Prom Night" has the cunning but mentally deranged Fenton turn the Prom Night ceremonies at the Grand Pacific Hotel into a house of horrors. Fenton is so unstable and blood thirsty that he ends up murdering a good number of the hotel staff who have nothing at all to do with keeping him and his "beloved" Donna apart! The guy-Fenton- also seems to have the power to travel from point A to Point B in some cases 20 to 30 miles apart on foot, he probably wore a pair of Air Jordans, faster then even a speeding police car, running red lights, could have done!

The local police headed by Det.Winn, Idris Elba, have more then their hands full in dealing with Fenton in that besides his ability to be a step or two ahead of them at every point in the movie he's also a master of disguise as well as expert in camouflaging himself. As we soon see Fenton can easily turn himself into a piece of furniture as well as any member of the hotel staff without anyone, including Det. Winn, ever noticing him!

***SPOILERS*** Donna who had enough troubles to deal with, in overcoming her deep psychiatric problems in seeing Fenton murder her entire family, is now confronted with the knowledge that not only is "Mad Dog" Fenton on the loose but had already murdered a good many of her high school friends, in his rampage at the senior Prom, including her one and only love, that she plans to marry after collage, her overprotective boyfriend Bobby, Scott Porter.

It was Fenton's big mistake in going after Donna at her Aunt and Uncle's home that turned out to be his own undoing. with the house surrounded by at least a dozen policemen Fenton's crazed love, or obsession, for Donna made him walk right into the trap that the cops set for him. But not after the slippery as an eel Fenton just about did them all in with only Det. Winn still around and on his feet in him being able to finally stop the crazed lunatic!

For me the movie didn't have much horror to it. It was mostly the actor who was being scared.

There is no hidden plot or mystery to this movie, what you see is what you get, but the actors were surprisingly good, and the movie was entertaining for what it's worth - which is saying a lot for a movie of this type.

The production is good, and everything is done with good quality. Still, it's hard to believe that this movie cost $20M to make, but it did good at the box office, so it did cater well to its target audience.

The movie is one of the best produced teenager based movie (I didn't say it's the best movie, teenage or otherwise - okay ?) I've seen, and I've enjoyed it because its integrity kept me watching 'till the end.

This movie was so bad that I could not even watch it's entirety. After about thirty minutes I was so terribly bored I went and found something else to watch. Too bad, too; I was hoping for something better.

See, I try to find the good in movies, and it was pretty hard to do for this one. Prom Night is a slasher movie, but there's no slashing. There wasn't A single death that was shown unless you saw the unrated cut I believe. The blood that is shown is very clearly fake. So can we even call it a slasher? This movies villain isn't interesting at all. And some of the parts try to build suspense, but fail because of how long it takes to happen. The only thing I can give this movie credit for is trying. And I guess its watchable, I didn't find it boring, but I can see how other people did for sure. I'm gonna have to recommend to skip Prom Night.

review_title: I wish I'd read the reviews first
review_detailed_main:
I saw Idris Elba was in this and thought that might mean it would be good. I was wrong. It wasn't in any way fun or entertaining. There weren't any suspenseful moments or even jump scares. It was slow and predictable.

Most slasher movies require some characters at some point to make bad decisions so that things can happen; but this one had everyone at every point making bad decisions.

Slasher movies also need the slasher to somehow be in the right place at the right time occasionally. This one had him at the right place at the right time every single time.

The police, that seem sharp for a minute, proceed to make every bad decision possible and not by accident or out of a lack of information.

None of the characters are likeable or interesting. Not once was there an "oh, no not that person!" when someone got killed.

It had good production value and some decent actors but the script seemed to have been written by a committee that must have said "Yeah, lets do that" to every bad idea anyone had.

review_title: Hopefully my prom night doesn't suck this much.
Ugh, what a typical slasher flick.
Idris Elba is why I watched this
review_detailed_main: I'm sure I've seen it several times and it's worth watching. I would have watched something else, but saw Idris was in it and he makes the show worth it. I've really come to like him as an actor. He is fantastic in "Luther"

review_title: Fine for a fourteen year old girl slumber party
review_detailed_main: "Prom Night" is not that bad a movie. It is a well produced, good looking film. The cast is very appealing and they all do a nice job. The women in this movie are quite dreamy. There's tons of cleavage which is always a plus. I think the problem is that the producers wanted/needed this movie to be PG-13. Given those constraints, I think screenwriter J.S. Cardone is a pretty good job. If this "Prom Night" was allowed to push an R rating, I think they really could have had something. As it is, "Prom Night" was worth watching and a good fit for young teenage viewers.

I loved this movie, i went to see it three different times in the theater last April. I know that ti was a remake, but it didn't really follow the same plot line as the 1980 flick. Don't get me wrong, i love both of them, but the 1980s Prom Night was more of a slasher flick and 2008's Prom Night is more of a suspense thriller, which totally rocked. If you are a fan of Brittany Snow and Jessica Stroup, like I am, then you will definitely die for this flick. Brittany Snow(John Tucker Must Die) finds herself target by an escaped mental patient Johnathan Schaech(The Forsaken and Hush), who comes after her three years later after targeting her and her family. When she goes to her senior prom with her close friends Jessica Stroup(90210 and Hills Have Eyes 2), Scott Porter, Dana Davis, Collins Pennie, Kelly Blatz, he hides inside the hotel, waiting to strike. As her friends begin to disappear, she must confront her past in hopes to survive the night. This movie really rocked, i like the ones with obsessive psychopaths and the things that they will do to express their love. So definitely check it out and its also a Screen Gems release.

review_title: a slasher flick with dumb cops
So bad I had to turn it off, yes it really is that bad.
review_detailed_main:
Horrible. I had to fast forward, a lot because I couldn't stomach this crap and new what was going on with all the sappy back-story and prom crap. These characters in this high school were so annoying I wanted them all to be brutally killed.

I really have no idea who would like this film, or who it was for. Maybe 12 year old girls would identify with the characters, or crazy deranged old men perhaps. Other than that I have no idea.

I hate turning off movies, and I rarely, if ever do so. But this was rated PG-13! If it was rated R I would have at least stayed around to watch it. Awful, sheer awfulness.

Donna is a high school student who is attending her senior prom. A obsessed high school teacher has escaped from his asylum who wants her.

I think this movie is okay and I wouldn't rate it a one. Her acting can be a little horrible at times but I find the movie like any other. Johnathon plays a very well serial killer and can look intimidating.

It's also interesting to see which actors careers have stood the test of time. Elba, for example, has gone on to do some great things, while others have seemingly faded into obscurity. Murphy, for example, has continued to be the "other Brittany ", despite her competition being dead. (Not much expectations for a blonde haired, blue eyed FL girl, I suppose) Prom Night stayed with all the cliches, minorities die first, the killer is everywhere despite never running, and don't look behind the open door. If they remade this in 2020, there would definitely not be as much hyper masculinity and a lot more racial diversity, but it was the early 2000s, so it is what it is. If you're watching this expecting any big plot twist or anything other than a very standard B-rated slasher flick, you WILL be disappointed. But if you shut off your brain and just enjoy it for the popcorn flick it is, you should have an okay time.

review_title: Friday the 13th in a grand hotel, but not as good
review_detailed_main:
...that's the best way to describe 2008's "Prom Night," which isn't a remake of the 1980 film. Brittany Snow plays the protagonist hounded by an ex-teacher who's psycho-obsessed with her. He escapes from prison and goes on a killing spree at the grand hotel where the prom is held. Jessica Stroup and Scott Porter are on hand as friends of the protagonist.

Being a PG-13 film there's not much gore, but I could care less because I'm more concerned with how interesting the story & characters are and not how much blood & guts are shown. While this is a well-done production -- costing $20 million -- the story & characters are only mildly interesting. The film never rises above mediocre to become something great or even good, but at least it's decent mediocre. For comparison, every single Friday the 13th film is more entertaining. Despite this, "Prom Night" was a minor hit at the box office, pulling in well over twice it's expense in the USA alone. Go figure.

Practically the entire movie takes place in a grand hotel, shot at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles. The flyover views of the spectacular bridge were shot in Newport, Oregon. The film runs 89 minutes.

GRADE: C+

Having survived a traumatic experience, a teenager and her friends decide to celebrate her senior prom when they learn one of her ex- teachers who harbored a psychotic crush on her has escaped from jail and is out stalking them at the hotel and must stop the madman.

There wasn't a whole lot here that actually worked for the film. One of the few bright spots is the fact that it gets off and running at a fairly early time, as there's a fairly fun pace to this moving along quite quickly here. It's barely half-an-hour into this one before the first attack comes and the relatively high body count works much more in it's favor since it starts knocking them off quite early on and gets the most out of these few sections. The only other fun part of the film is that it's got a couple of really entertaining stalking scenes which are better than expected and are quite enjoyable at times, as the first stalking scene in the under- construction segment is rather good, with the creepy setting coming into fantastic use, the action is really nice and the whole sequence works really nice as well as a really good sequence where he stalks her within the hotel room that is quite good and a little intense at times. These here are the film's overall best qualities as there's a whole lot of problems with this one that really hold it down. One of the main ones is that this one is just so tame as the kills are just done with a simple knife. To have them be singularly stabbings is where it really fails by not offering any creativity to the kills with this one since it's incredibly embarrassing to witness the kills in this as there's hardly anything to see when the stab-wounds aren't visible at all, merely marked by a small red dot on the article of clothing near the area where the knife entered. That's considering that you can even tell where the kill took place as most of the time this is edited in such a way as to make sure that the official killing method isn't determined so as to make sure that no one is really offended by this one. That seems to it's entire spiel, to be sure that no one is offended, as there's no blood or gore during the kills, the ones we can see are so tame a kindergartner wouldn't be offended at it, offers no nudity or sleaze despite this being about prom night for high-schoolers and features a resulting feel of just being so completely tame and harmless that it's really almost enough to knock it down because of that. Another problem is a completely glossed-over back-story that really doesn't do much of anything to explain rationale, motives, or anything at all. Rather, it's just explicitly stated as being a crush and the one time something could've been done with it, the keeping of journals with photos and thoughts about her, nothing is done. It's a grand missed- opportunity to really give this one something to it, and it fails on that mark badly. The last big flaw to this one is the fact that the never-ending series of utter stupidity presented from everybody here. The characters' constantly go wandering off by themselves to investigate the disappearance of their friends, all of which is done at the exact same area which makes them really stupid, but the biggest ones goes to the police for failing to inform others of what has happened. That should've been top-priority once news leaked of the escape, yet that doesn't happen and really makes them look foolish once this happened. All of these here lower this one considerably.

Rated PG-13: Violence and Language.

review_title: From a Whisper to a Whimper
review_detailed_main:
Not that I liked "Prom Night" (1980) with Jamie Lee Curtis, but this movie had no relation to that one. This "Prom Night" was generally weak and uninspired.

A crazed maniac ex-teacher named Richard Fenton (Johnathon Schaech), who was infatuated with his student Donna Keppel (Brittany Snow), killed her entire family so that she'd only have him. He was locked up for that only to break out of the insane asylum and travel 2300 miles to try to reclaim Donna on her prom night. The only real protection Donna had was Detective Winn (Idris Elba) who could only do so much.

What we got was typical high school movie drama interspersed with some tempered killing to maintain that sacred PG-13 rating (which did the movie no favors). "Prom Night" began as a loud whisper and ended with a faint whimper.

K. I would love to punch the people in the mouth that think up these lame movies. I don't even know how the old movie was but this movie had no ending even waiting for. I was able to call every scene before it happened.

Lets go over it...Man gets out of Crazy bin, Nobody knows about it, wow, What a surprise, its too late!!! hello? Then you have him killing everyone in the movie that have no reason to be killed and every scene you see coming from a mile away. The Prom King and Queen should have been able to kick ass and take names in this movie. In stead you have the whole sad story how the the man wanted to ask his girl to marry him but wow, she dies! Why even put the little nice story with them in it.

No good ending.

Yea, great, she lived in the end but all of her friends are dead and she will end up in the loony bin the rest of her life! Did the writers go on strike again?

Than lower them again. I did like the original movie better. In this one the story is non existent. This just goes on and on. The characters are bland. Brittany Snow's acting is tentative and terrible.

Only two redeeming qualities: Idris Elba as the driven cop and Jonathon Schaech whose especially good at playing a very disturbed former teacher/murderer. Save this movie for when you've seen everything else and you are bored out of your mind.

But once again another surprise happened. The black girl died instead of her. If they really wanted it to be a complete horror movie more people should have died. Yet they made it work. In my opinion good movie. But could've been better. If they're planning to make a sequel to this movie or a prequel film. I'm looking forward to it. People who say it's a bad movie OK understandable. People who say it's a great movie you're probably out of your mind. Prom Night was good just not too good.
