review_title: Not as bad as I expected
review_detailed_main:
OK, I gave this a 5, on the basis that I watch 30-50 horror movies a year so believe I have a fairly balanced view on what makes a good and bad horror flick.

I have seen many terrible films in the genre recently and whilst this one offers little which is original, it's not a flawed as many of the others.

It is relatively enjoyable but falls short in some departments - e.g. there is no real mystery at all in this horror film. That alone is quite unusual for a horror flick involving teenagers and school kids etc.

On that note the casting is bad. I mean its not unusual for directors to cast actors older than they actually are. But this film cast near actors who looked near 30 to play teenage prom kids. It really did detract from the look and feel of the film.

The other note on casting is that strangely the main killer is very good looking. Whilst many horror flicks involves a creepy mask and so on, this guy is not creepy at all to look at. Very strange indeed - and even though I am a hetero sexual male it made me very unphased by staring at this killer who is meant to freak me out. It simply didn't. I was even contemplating how 'cool' his look was.

Whilst there are obvious flaws in "why didn't she do this and that" throughout they are by far not that noticeable compared to other similar horror flicks.

I was quite surprised this film received a 3 overall. I thought it deserved at least a point or two more than that.

I'd comfortably give this film a 5. Merely for the fact that although its not original in story, it does follow a strange pattern where what you expect to happen half way through doesn't entirely happen. Without spoiling it I'll leave it at that.

Worth it if you are under 30 and like films like the craft/urban legend. If you are older you may find it a little hard to swallow being more mature and all.

review_title: I love Brittany Snow, but I was sad.
review_detailed_main:
The problem with Prom Night is the same problem that so many remakes have. Relevance (or lack thereof). They're so busy trying to keep you distracted from the lack of a sensible plot that between jump scenes (albeit well done ones, at times), they forget to tie things in. Random bits of plot are thrown in to keep you from wondering what exactly the point of the movie is, or what it's even trying to say, or why you care are all. There were a dozen times during the movie where, had the director not been afraid to push a little further, he could have done something that wasn't so ... well, predictable. Maybe, in the future, McCormick should stick to directing TV shows.

You have to feel bad for Brittany Snow who tried her best, but clearly wasn't given too much to work with. Then again J.S. Cardone did write The Forsaken and Wicked Little Things; both similar to the remake of Prom Night in that the plot didn't push where it should have, or pull back where it should have. Good original concepts, but without that edge they became just a few more dime-a-dozen, poorly executed movies with decent make up effects (or CGI, as the case may be).

I will give the movie a few points for the few properly executed jump-shots (even though I have to take said points away for the many many painfully obvious and predictable ones) and for the good filming. Also, props to Johnathon Schaech for his creepy intensity (but then again he was also one of the few saving graces in The Forsaken).

review_title: The best part is the credits.

review_detailed_main:
Well, it's a raining day and I had nothing better to do so I did what I've been avoidingwatching this movie.

Afterwards, I read the IMDb reviews and was somewhat shocked at all the negative reactions to the film because it really wasn't that bad. Most of the negative reviews were about the LACK of blood and gore in the movie and how that was a betrayal of the "genre." Apparently to some, the "slasher genre" requires a certain body count as well as a certain "yuk" factor in order to be valid.

There's no question here that the film makers are trying to "break rules." I like that. Out the gate, I'd give them a 5 for trying to do something different and trying to change the genre. That's what "Scream" did. It changed the genre and reinvented it.

First broken rule, as noted, this isn't a "blood and gore" flick. They've specifically minimized that which is apparent from the PG-13 rating as well as the opening scenes. Those wanting more should have walked out at the opening (or shut off the DVD). There's no sense waiting for something that isn't going happen.

The second rule that's broken is that the killer doesn't invisibly sulk around the fringes of the film while committing his mayhem. In fact, the physical appearance of the killer is very much a part of the unfolding story. To further this, they've even cast a "hottie" as the killer; someone whose screen presence is more likely to delight rather than cause fear. This is a very significant deviation from the expected.

Another rule that was broken was that bodies weren't discovered until later in the movie. This means that our "core characters" don't wander off in the face of danger. Of course, they still wander off to their fates, but not with the usual setups. Instead, they event some equally implausible setups to bring the killer and victims together.

However, that's where the rule breaking ends and the regular genre rules come back into play.

There's the usual "false jump" shots where something could happen but doesn't.

The cops are only marginally competent and end up being simply more "cannon fodder" for the killer/stalker.

The worst though is that there is no character development. The teens are all just "eye candy." There's nothing special about any of them and they are all interchangeable. You can go down the checklist of possible characteristics and find only the expected. There's the "going off to college" conflict(s). There's the "who is going to be Prom Queen? There's the horny teens going off to propose marriage/have sex. Even the main character has only one individual characteristic in that the killer tried to get to her before. But, beyond that, she's a vacuum. The stalker/killer also has no character. He "wants" Donna (our main character) but we don't really know why which would actually seem to be critical if want any kind of believability.

As such, I don't think the film makers have advanced too far in challenging the genre. They've made some positive efforts but have fallen way short of making something different and unique. A few more steps in new directions could have given us our "next generation" for the genre. Instead, we'll have to wait for someone else to finish those steps.

review_title: How were all these people walking around without any blood in their bodies?
review_detailed_main:
This is not "so bad its good", this is just bad.

The lack of blood was really comical. I know this is PG-13, but it felt PG.

Stabbed to death in a white tile bathroom? No blood.

Stabbed to death on a bed with white sheets? No blood.

Throat slashed while laying down on white sheets in a white shirt? No blood!

If there had been any blood then he might have been caught a little faster. They could have tried a little harder to make the décor darker colors, but they kept as much stuff as bright white as they could.

Ironically, blood dripping from the ceiling is leveraged by the detective, but when they drag the body out... there is no blood.

Here are other things that are bad:

-Bodies vanished almost instantly when someone walked into rooms moments after a killing -He killed the maid for her key card, then later killed a guy who simply asked him if he saw the maid recently.

-The plot is dreadfully predictable, not even offering jump scares, let alone any semblance of horror.

-Similarly, they tell you who the killer is and where he is immediately, so I'm not sure why they tried to add "mystery" to the genre.

-The characters are so poorly written that its like there is no dialogue at all and you couldn't care less when they die.

-A bunch of 29 year old dudes playing the high school boyfriends and looking like dads

review_title: Does Absolutely Nothing to Improve on Anything and Doesn't Even make for a Better Story
review_detailed_main:
The remake of "Prom Night"???? What was the point. I never saw the point in them remaking the original because the underrated 80's slasher film itself was on a decent level and it wasn't anything special at all. Sure it brought another slasher to the table but still. It didn't need a remake because it's an untouchable classic like "Halloween" or "The Omen". It didn't need a remake because there was nothing to improve on at all! The remake is a totally different film and serves no purpose to the original at all. It sucks and it just sucks. People who love the original (not like me) will be gutted if they see it. The remake basically stars cheap actors and then there's Britney Snow. The remake's story is departed from the original as well.

This girl's parents get killed by an overly obsessed teacher who wants to be with the girl dearly. He gets taken to prison and that's that. A few months (I don't know) how many what ever's later she is going to her senior prom with here boyfriend. The teacher manages to escape and he follows, stalks and kills his way through the Prom to get to her.

I hated this film. The minute I got watching, the minute I wished I had turned it off. I mean why???? It didn't need a remake because the original was so good, just mentioning again it didn't need the remake because there is nothing to improve on. Remakes are purely done these days for money and not for improving on. Out of 100% most of them are OK but never improve on the original movie.

This was just crazy. The CGI-effects were put to good use and serve no purpose. The actors are crappy and I was disappointed with Britney Snow's performance here. She did so well in "Hair Spray" but here, my gosh she was awful. The killer is not imitating nor is he scary. A guy in a baseball cap and a suit does not make for a scary killer. Many kill scenes are done the same and they are laughably boring. There was no suspense build up at all.

Overall, the original was a decent/average film which was actually watchable. Here, it's definitely not the case. Here there is no improvement. They should have put so much more effort into this remake. When you do a remake, you are trying to improve on the original. That's what I would do if I chose to remake something (which in most cases I would never do that). Like the "The Fog" remake, it is a wasted shred of film, and deserves to be forgotten. It does absolutely nothing to improve on anything and doesn't even make for a better story! 0/10

After the traumatic murder of her family, Donna Keppel(B. Snow) is just starting to rebuild her life. On the night of her senior prom her family's psychotic killer escapes from the mental institution to come and get what he wantedDonna.

Because this movie is PG-13 it was guaranteed no violence and no gore, in which could have made up for the terrible murder scenes. No suspense what-so-ever, all the murders follow the same murderer in the closet/behind you in the mirror style, which made every murder more and more annoying.

The entire movie was basically a give away, because of the lack of twists and poorly written script. There was only really one twist that I didn't predict and basically the only twist in the entire script.

Although the setting was beautiful it was very far-fetched for this film. It wasn't realistic what-so-ever.

I can't complain about the camera work, the camera covered all angles of the prom and in the hotel rooms.

The acting wasn't terrible, but it wasn't great either. Brittany Snow almost under reacted in some scenes, but I think overall she was delivered a decent performance. Jonathan Schaech registered extremely well as the chilling killer. But I wasn't impressed with the rest of the acting.

So, overall this film delivered cheap scares, a terrible script, no plot, and decent acting.

Overall 3/10

review_title: A neutered in name only remake of a movie that wasn't even that good in the first place
review_detailed_main:
Three years after Donna Keppel (Brittany Snow) survived a home invasion by a former teacher, Richard Fenton (Johnathon Schaech), who became psychotically obsessed with her, Donna now lives with her aunt and uncle and coping with lingering trauma from the event. Donna is now looking forward to her attending her high school prom with her firends and her boyfriend at the luxurious Pacific Palace Hotel, but unknown to Donna Richard has broken out of jail and now seeks to finish what he started spurring Detective Winn (Idris Elba) to action to try and stop him.

2008's Prom Night followed a wave of remakes spurred by the success of Michael Bay/Platinum Dune's remake of Texas Chainsaw Massacre which became a sleeper hit and encouraging remakes of other classic horror films (House of Wax, Friday the 13th, The Fog, etc.). In Prom Night's case, the film was an attempt Neal H. Moritz' Original Film and Prom Night rights' holders Aliance to reboot the long dormant Prom Night series for the modern era. While the Prom Night was a respectable hit at the box office back in the day owing mainly to being one of the earliest in the wave of films that made the 1980s slasher glut, retrospective reviews haven't look back as fondly upon the film as Friday the 13th or other contemporaries. I myself didn't hate the movie and appreciated some good performances and a well done third act finale, but most of the original Prom Night is a meandering bore as we wait a really long time for four people involved in a prank gone wrong years ago to get their comeuppance as the movie impotently tries to throw us off with Red Hearings that mean absolutely nothing since a flashback sequence that begins the movie makes it painfully obvious who did it and why. With that said, there was a decent enough foundation for a remake to tackle the same material and do it better, but unfortunately not only is Prom Night '08 an "in name only" remake, it doesn't even put the name to good effect stripping away even the good elements that made Prom Night worth viewing.

From the opening frame of Prom Night '08, the movie makes the wrong impression. Playing an angsty remix of "it's the time of the season" overlooking idyllic pacific Northwest coastal towns the movie let's you know it's from the same production house behind films such as The Skulls, I Know What You Did Last Summer, and Urban Legends sporting an overly polished look that makes the film feel like the teen drama pilot for The WB rather than a horror film. Even when we do get to the opening horror the movie undercuts itself in two ways by 1) putting it in the extremely predictable framework of a dream sequence and 2) a PG-13 rating that can't allow any visceral impact. Even when taking the horror out of the equation the movie is obnoxiously loud, vapid, and over cut as many times it feels like a promo fro an MTV reality show collided with a music video. The movie's over usage of angsty pop and stuttering club beats might have been forgivable if it was diegetic sound that made up the Prom, but no, from the get go these music choices are hard coded into the soundtrack for the audience to hear and not the characters. This is one of many missteps the movie takes as it feels like it's a teen drama trying to fight against being a horror film.

Things aren't much better character wise. Brittany Snow's Donna is supposed to be suffering from PTSD (and also recently off her anxiety medication for reasons frankly too stupid to go into) but throughout the film she seems perfectly fine gabbing and giggling with her friends, hanging out of limo rooftops, and attending a prom that is so overdone complete with bouncers and red carpet that even most award ceremonies would challenge it to "tone down". Aside from our inconsistent lead, the movie's group is filled with all manner of characters who are either bland, stereotypical, or one note. The one bright spot in the movie is Idris Elba as Detective Winn who brings his usually A game of relaxed masculine charisma that makes him such an appealing presence, but he's basically a glorified plot device who isn't allowed to act and put a stop to everything because if he did the movie would only be about 30 maybe 40 minutes long if he did.

Prom Night is an awful and vapid movie. It takes a mediocre but serviceable 80s slasher film and replacing anything that worked from the original with sanitized PG-13 kills, erratic editing, and an idiot plot that would be over if the characters had two brain cells to rub together. While not the worst from this period of horror remakes, it still can't even justify its own existence.

If you enjoyed Prom Night (2008), then I feel bad for you. Because you have been lied to throughout your undoubtedly short life by many people and institutions. Mostly though, you've been lied to by yourself. This is less of a movie and more of a giant commercial for everything that is wrong with our dying nation. This crap-fest has nothing to do with the mildly enjoyable predecessor that it shares the same name with. Other than the name "Prom Night", the only thing it has in common with the original is that there is a prom. Only now, Proms apparently are more glamorous that any Oscar celebration and there are no long fat people or kids with acne in high school. Plus, money is no object for the most annoying characters you'll ever endure. Never have I rooted more for a killer in a horror film. They spared us any suspense by showing us who the killer is in the first 4 minutes of the film. From there on the viewer is subjected to painful dialog and unbearable music that fills each ocean of time between the letdown killings. Everyone in this turd acts embarrassed to be there, as they should. Any evil person or group to churn out crap like this onto the public and stamp the name "Prom Night" on it should hang there head in shame at the disservice they have imposed on their fellow humans. The way this movie sucks so effortlessly is a reflection of how the United States is fast slipping into the footnote of history. Prom Night (2008) is a simple reminder that all is lost and that we deserve the demise that awaits us. After watching this, I realize that we are now one step closer to oblivion. I hate this movie. Not even God can help us anymore. Prom Night (2008) will forever scar my brain with its putrid and unyielding assault on everything that is good in this world. Hunting down and destroying every last copy of Prom Night (2008) may not undue the damage that it has inflicted upon our universe, but it is a start that may protect future generations from such careless and irresponsible film-making.

I think the most telling thing about this movie is that I literally just watched it ten minutes before writing this and I can't really remember much about it. It's so remarkably unremarkable. That's made all the worse by Idris Elba. The man just can't turn it off, he's too good, too intense for this movie. He doesn't belong here and every scene he's in draws stark contrast to the mediocrity everywhere else.

I really wish more of this movie had been from his perspective. The hardened, intelligent cop chasing the killer a la Se7en. Would have been a vast improvement to this, whatever this was. But we live with what we have and in this case it's not a lot. Can only imagine slasher diehards getting anything from this, not really worth everyone else's time.

Anyone bored with mediocre horror films had better get used to them. Even this film made some good money. With its PG-13 rating, and millions of parents looking to get their teens out of the house for a couple hours, this film couldn't miss. Thank goodness I saw this film at home and not in the company of a hundred or so teenagers in a theater...

I guess this is a remake of an old Jamie Lee Curtis film from the early 1980s. Oddly enough, I've seen just about all of those old horror films a million times each, yet I don't recall seeing that one. Hard to imagine it was any worse. The story here deals with a deranged former teacher breaking out of prison to murder a teen on her senior prom night. It seems he killed her whole family 3 years earlier in some bizarre effort to win her over. Honestly dude, I don't think that was the best way to go! The girl is played by the fetching Brittany Snow who may or may not have a decent career ahead of her. I liked her performance, actually. She and her classmates are having their prom at a swanky hotel in the Portland area. One thing that struck me is the supposedly most bitchy (think Rachel McAdams from Mean Girls minus the talent) girl in school had her dad pay thousands of dollars for the whole thing. Apparently in an attempt to get the prom queen crown rapped up for his daughter. Anyway, that would be a hell of a generous gesture for anyone to do for a senior class. Yet the protagonist kids still rip on her at every chance.

The killer in the film is played by Jonathon Schaech, a man whose career once looked brighter than it now does. Recall him as Jimmy from That Thing You Do? He was the arrogant band leader and boyfriend of Liv Tyler. He dated Christina Applegate in real life for years. Any way, in the opening scenes of this film he is a dead ringer for one of those Geico cavemen. Later on, once he's broken out of prison and killing the teenagers, he has cleaned up a bit. Only now, he's a dead ringer for Billy Bob Thornton whenever he wears a baseball cap!! You have to see it to believe both resemblances! The kids and hotel staff are picked off in a series of predictable and not the least bit gory scenes. Really nothing scary about the film, you just might have a bit more trouble than usual predicting who lives or dies.

Some random observations...... Did I hear a product plug for Midol?? Do most maids clean rooms during prime time hours? There are at least two early scenes where our killer finally has the girl of his dreams all alone in the suite and does NOTHING with her!! Uh huh. He's been obsessing for how long? How many films have we now seen the dead detective in the car outside on the stakeout? Let's see.... Black Christmas, Tightrope,... help me out here, people. It's only one of the oldest clichés ever. Watch if you must. I had to, because like the dirty older guys in the elevator, I find high school girls delicious! 5 of 10 stars.

The Hound

review_title: Doesn't deserve the bashing it's getting
review_detailed_main:
I think sometimes it's fashionable for everyone to hate, or at least state they hate, a film. A couple of years ago it was 'I Know Who Killed Me' and with both these films, I watched them with an open mind and found them both to be fun. entertaining and stylish movies, that really didn't deserve the critical bashing they got.

No Prom Night doesn't resemble the original- but if there's one thing Gus Van Sant's Psycho remake taught me, a remake that sticks too closely to it's source material is more interesting in concept than execution. It's the same with US remakes of East Asian horror- while most people are raving about how fantastic The Ring is, those who have seen the original are bored by it's uninspired retelling. I want people to take the source material and roll with it, I want new ideas, a completely new take- because if I wanted to watch the same film twice, I'd replay the original, not venture out to the DVD store. Perhaps this is the reason I was very impressed by Rob Zombie's Halloween- well at least the first half.

Prom Night reminds me of the slasher films I fell in love with during the 90's- horror was given a boost after Scream and fun, hip films like I Know What You Did Last Summer, The Faculty and, to a lesser extent, Urban Legend were out in cinemas, and for a teenager who grew up on horrors, it was heaven. Prom Night is a tight film, with likable characters, breezy dialogue, some slick cinematography, and some genuinely tense moments. There's so much horror out there that drags on, perhaps under the misplaced belief that it's building tension, but this film hits the ground running, and keeps going.

It's not especially original, some of the shots of the Prom Night partiers feels a little bit too music video which comes across as trying too hard to be cool, but the film kept me watching, and interested all the way through.

With regards to the gore, this film doesn't need it. I watched the unrated DVD, which apparently only adds a minute of blood splats here and there, but even without this I don't think this film would feel neutered- because this film isn't about gore. It's not like the DVD of My Bloody Valentine I watched recently, where the cuts to gore were so apparent that the film felt like it had lost something important- like I was watching the shreds of what was left after a major edit.

Prom Night was never made to depend on gore to draw it's audience in- you get a coherent fun little film despite this. And at a time when so many horror films rely on gore, torture and sadism, it's nice to have a film that almost feels like a more simplistic, even innocent, entry into the genre- one where you want the girl to survive, not wondering what gruesome way she can be murdered.

review_title: This film for being a remake of a classic is disappointing
review_detailed_main: Prom Night (2008) is currently available on Netflix and tells the tale of a young lady with a traumatic past. A man from her past that was obsessed with her, tracked her down and murdered members of her family trying to get to her has escaped the asylum and is looking for her...on her prom night. This movie is directed by Nelson McCormick (The Stepfather, 2009) and stars Brittany Snow (Pitch Perfect 1 & 2), Idris Elba (Thor), Johnathon Schaech (Ray Donovan), Scott Porter (Speed Racer) and Brianne Davis (Jarhead). The storyline for this picture is very straightforward and fairly cliche. The kill scenes are also mediocre and lack gore and intensity. This film has a great cast but they're underused and suffer from a script and storyline that's underwhelming. This film for being a remake of a classic is disappointing. I'd score this a 2/10 and recommend skipping it.

review_title: I felt bad Idris Elba was stuck in this

review_detailed_main: Although the acting was reasonable, and the plot was something to look at, this movie is not worth seeing whether in theaters or on DVD. My friend had loaned it to me one weekend, and even though she had warned me how bad it was, I ignored her and went onto watching it. Boy was she right... To me, this 'horror' flick turned out to be a crappy teenage movie, something 14-year-olds would watch with their boyfriends on a Friday night. The style itself reminded me too much of movies like "My Life as a Teenaged Drama Queen" or "Bring it On", and in my opinion horror movies shouldn't even be near that genre. If I were anybody, I'd stick with "The Exorcist" and "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre". At least those provided good scares.

review_title: A below par remake of a below par movie.
review_detailed_main:
As far as the genre goes, this is hardly the worst movie to watch out there. But just like its original it's also far from the best. It's not very original and it doesn't seem to know what it wants to do and be, which strangely enough was also something that the 1980 original movie suffered from, even though both movies are very different from each other in story and approach.

This movie basically has very little to do with the 1980 movie "Prom Night", which starred Jamie Lee Curtis. Not that that's necessarily a bad thing though. The original movie also really wasn't a great one to begin with. It's basically only a sequel in name and only basically uses the idea of letting murders take place during a prom night. The story and all of its characters are totally different and so is the killer, which is not a good thing though.

Thing about its killer is that we know who it is. We see him commit all of the murders and we even know what his motivations are. So there is totally no mystery about it who is the killer in this movie, which already takes away lots of the movie its tension as well. It besides isn't a very strong villain. He doesn't act very smart and only seems to unnecessarily get himself into more trouble when he needlessly kills lots of people. The actor besides didn't impressed me, as did none of the actors in this movie really.

It's one of those movies in which a bunch of teenagers get portrayed by people in their 20's. They are over-the-top ridiculously beautiful and perfect and are all oh so friendly all of the time. The characters were all quite annoying, though I must admit that I kind of liked Kellan Lutz in this, though his role is extremely small. All of the actors are kind of acting in this as if they are big stars already who are going to make it big time. I have some news for them; no one is going to know who you are in 10 years from now and no one knows who you are now either by the way. Except for Kellan Lutz, who I for some reason predict a great future, most likely in the action genre.

The story doesn't really provide the movie with much originality. The movie isn't really being a slasher, which should be a big disappointment for the genre fans but I have no clue as well what the movie is being. Not scary, not bloody, not surprising...I know what the movie is not being. It's a very cliché filled movie that doesn't even handle its clichés well. A lacking movie that can perhaps be best described as a teenage-thriller, without thrills and real teenagers though.

But nothing about this movie makes me say that it's a completely horrible or unwatchable one. It's lacking on basically every department yes, but nothing about it makes me hate this movie. Perhaps it's just that I have seen some far worse movies. But anyway, no, it's not a movie that I would ever recommend to anybody watching.

5/10

http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

review_title: Worst movie of 2008, worst horror movie...flat out the worst movie ever.
this didn't need to be remade
review_detailed_main:
Are Hollywood really running out of ideas, because all we seem to get these days are remakes after remakes. And now they're starting on the 80's slashers, they've already butchered scream queen Jamie Lee Curtis's horror's Halloween and The Fog and now they've turned they're attention to Prom Night, an almost forgotten but decent little slasher gem from the 80's.

Although Prom Night was by no means a classic or pefect, but it was great and had moments of suspense, in which this version doesn't. There's absolutely no scares or tension in this remake, and to top it all off no gore equals crappy murder scenes. The killer was just rubbish he wasn't menacing or scary, just some guy with an ugly mug.

The only good point in this version is Brittany Snow, who plays the main heroine,who does a pretty decent job given the crap material she's got to star in, only one hopes that this pile of rubbish doesn't ruin her career.

All in all this movie isn't even mediorce at best.

I saw this movie by myself and though my friends had said it want scary and was boring, I however thought the movie was good! The teacher DEFINITELY freaked me out every tine he was gonna kill somebody. He was very creepy and, dare I say, creepy and crazy! Donna and everyone else were innocent victims in the whole ordeal and I was actually shocked every time he killed someone. I was especially shocked when he killed the boys but I understand, in the teachers twisted mind, that ANYONE in the way between him and Donna would have to go. I can't believe people said that some people said the movie was not scary because I was almost scared when, at the beginning of the movie, when Donna remembers finding her ENTIRE family dead because of the teacher, I was almost scared and creeped out SOOOOOOOOOOOOO bad!! When one of the detectives is detectives about Donna's case with her past teacher and her family, it's scary HOW infatuated he was with Donna and what lengths he would go to to be with her!! You would think that he would have somewhat of a mind to understand what a restraining order is and how to live by the rules but NO!!! Keeps going, gets locked behind bars, sent away to the looney bin; hopefully that would say something like: "hey, I might be crazy but I can fix it if I work at it." but, he doesn't and gets the punishment he deserves. Anyway, the movie was good, scary, shocking, and having me wonder if my teachers in high school ever had a crush or infatuation with me..........

review_title: Not that great of a horror remake
review_detailed_main: Prom night the remake just isn't that great of a movie. The acting is pretty wooden and phoned in. The writing and script is run of the mill and horribly cliché. There were some entertaining moments, some of the kills were kinda thrilling and some of the action/running sequences were fun and had a little adrenaline. But the overall plot was just so cliché and been there done that that it was kinda hard to overlook. Brittany snow (John Tucker must die) was enjoyable as the lead, and Kellan Lutz (Twilight) is alright I suppose, the rest of the cast are just cardboard cut out characters that fall flat. The violence wasn't too graphic or gory, it was PG-13 level goriness, which was good, I thought an R rating would've been too much considering teens are the target audience for this remake. 4/10 for the 2008 remake of prom night.

Nothing and I mean nothing to do with the original ,save for the title and the fact that it takes place on Prom Night. A formal apology should be presented to Jamie Lee Curtis for this atrocity.

Was this R? Heck no, it's more like PG 13. No Thrills, No Gore, No T&A, no 15 chase scene with the villain and heroine, no plot... and the Killer. For Petes sake wear a mask. Groucho Marx, Willam Shatner, even a black ski mask would have been better than a baseball cap.

The supporting actors are just written in for the sheer sake of dying. Pretty boys and girls with their pretty shallow Beverly hills lives. For that alone they deserved to die. If this movie was geared towards teenagers, then I'm glad I was one in the 80's. At least my horror movies were scary.

best part of the movie were the end credits where the song Paralyzed was played. Exactly how I felt after watching this wannabe horror flick.

Please,no more hacking and slashing of our precious horror classics. There is just no way a remake can surpass the original. Unless the original was a flop to begin with. Now if this gets a make over in say, 20 years, it will surely be better.LOL! Final thoughts: This would have been better suited for television on say ...the WC network. I actually saw one of the actresses on the premier last night of 90210 and on the WC network.LOL!
This movie feels like a 10 year old told a horror story at the camp fire and made it into a movie when they got older...because it's TRASH

review_title: It had such Potential...but came out Horribly Wrong!!!!
Wow. Can it get any worse than this?
review_detailed_main: Seriously, this movie was nearly unwatchable. My biggest problem with this movie was just how absolutely atrocious the script was. The "scare" moments were laughably predictable. To be fair, I have no problem with any of the actors. Nearly all them were more than serviceable and I honestly had no problem believing any of them were teenagers enjoying their senior prom. I can't understate this enough... The acting and dialogue were pretty darn good. The strength of the performances were enough to lift this movie from a 1/10 to a 3/10 for me, but everything else about this movie just fails so miserably. All of the dramatic set up and so-called "tension" was forced and poorly constructed and it ruined any chance this movie had for working. I counted 3 occasions in which supposedly dead bodies suddenly became animated and just fell out of places. Is this thing a zombie flick? I understand the limitations that a PG-13 rating forces upon a movie, hence the liberal use of the cheap scare tactics, but that was the least of this movie's problems... It felt less like a PG-13 movie and more like a 13 year old wrote it.

review_title: Superb Horror Film But Something Much More
review_detailed_main: Gifted director Nelson McCormick has simply done an inspired job of bringing J.S. Cordone's brilliant screenplay to the screen. The shocks and thrills come fast and furiously from the very opening scene to the shattering climax. However, it is the sensitively observed portrait of a traumatized young girl going through a profound life transition that makes this motion picture so much more than a horror film. The film has its share of blood and gore but it never diminishes the development of the central character. A superb performance by Brittany Snow brings depth and humanity to her role of Donna Keppel and it is a deeply moving portrayal. Certainly a unique genre film as it departs from the expected and will surprise audiences in many ways.

Ever since Carrie turned her senior prom into a no-holds-barred free-for-all of revenge, mayhem and murder, we've been subjected to one bloodbath after another set at that annual rite of passage for pimply-faced teens. You might think that the remake of "Prom Night" could not possibly be more hackneyed and predictable than the 1980 original – but you'd be wrong. In fact, there is not one original idea to be found in this film, neither in its storytelling nor in its filmmaking style.

Brittany Snow plays the pretty blond teen whose entire family was massacred three years earlier by an obsessed teacher who, at the time, looked like only a slightly more maniacal version of Charlie Manson. Now, it's prom night and the killer, all cleaned-up and ready for action, has just escaped from prison, determined to finally claim Donna for his own (though whether he wants her alive or dead is never made entirely clear). Thus, as the revelers dance the night away in the ballroom below, an assortment of whiny, horny teenagers – and various hotel staff – meet their untimely ends in the poorly lit suites above.

Nelson McCormick's directorial style consists entirely of obvious point-of-view shots, false scares and images of people popping up in mirrors at inconvenient (though entirely predictable) moments. The greatest waste is that of Scott Porter and Idris Elba who are both so good in their respective TV series ("Friday Night Lights" and "The Wire"), but who have been given absolutely nothing of interest or quality to work with here.

The movie Prom Night was very good. I thought that everything turned out to be done very well. It kept my attention through the whole movie and everything that happened in the movie. I believe that the majority of people that watch Prom Night will find out that it is good, and that they will want to see it over. Brittany Snow and the other Actors including the Directors and everyone else did a great job putting this movie together. It was enjoying and the movie actually turned out better than I thought it would. You could follow the plot and climax through the whole movie and you could figure out when things were about to happen. But I am not going to spoil the movie you have to watch it and find out what you think of it on your own... ENJOY THE MOVIE

I can't believe this was a remake of the all time classic horror movie "prom night" starring Jamie lee Curtis( who was great in that movie)

but this movie was completely stupid!!! it was like watching a bunch of people who lines where so terrible it made every horror movie fan run out of the theater screaming for all the wrong reasons! this film is a complete failure i could believe this film was called a film!!it was more like a mockery of the 1980 film( with the same name) why is this film was made? because it was to reach to the new age horror movie. guess what? that didn't work!!! it's better to keep the old one the way it was, instead of trying to make it look like crap!

Prom Night isn't much more than a paint-by-numbers slasher movie. There's nothing really new or creative about this flick and, to make matters worse, it's was forced to have a dreaded PG-13 rating. It has a pretty predictable plot that trudges along well enough and features a killer who can occasionally be way too unrealistic in the way he's able to slice and dice his victims without much of a fight and without any detection. With all that being said though, I do also feel like the hate towards this horror remake is (a little) too strong. I think any massive fan of the slasher genre will find a way to have a good time with this.

Straightforward boring remake in the post-Halloween style about a group of friends during their prom night finding themselves on the run from a serial killer. There is no such thing as suspense or 3D characteristics, and it rehashes all of the genre clichés, which makes you feel that you've seen it all a dozen times before. People move around in corridors and rooms, where lights flicker, with the murderer lurking around in the shadows, and so there is suddenly a squeaky sound, and it's a big SOUND OF NOISE supposed to make you jump, but oh (!) it was nothing, but oh, wait, it was something after all, it was... the killer. Sadly the killer is one of the less effective I've seen in a horror film, mostly because you see his face all the time (a handsome face too), and he's a romantic at heart, and he uses a small, jagged knife that would look better on a cheeseboard table, and he wears a cap. When the killer and his chosen one battles throughout the latter parts of the film, they sound more like a married couple arguing. And the prom night dramatics are truly terrible, as we shuffle through kings and queens, slow dances, DJ music, partying and school nostalgia. This is bad American teenage horror.

review_title: It'll put you off a prom for life, and not in the way you might think so

review_detailed_main: Now, I know for a fact that I've seen the original "Prom Night" (released in 1980 and starring Jamie Lee Curtis) at one point in my life, but it was so mundane and insignificant that I don't actually remember anything about it. In other words I haven't got the slightest idea why specifically this slasher deserved the remake treatment, but apparently it doesn't matter, as the new version is a remake "in name only". One could claim there definitely are some plot-similarities between the two movies, but then again, nearly ALL teen-slasher movies feature these prototypic characteristics. As dreaded but expected, "Prom Night 2008" is an incredibly redundant, politically correct and frustratingly routine new horror movie that contributes a great deal in giving the genre a bad reputation nowadays. The movie nonetheless opens mildly promising; with a modern reworked version of the song "Time of the Season" (the original sung by The Zombies would even have been better of course, but still) and some niftily shot images during the opening credits. Immediately after that, it's just a never-ending spitfire of dull clichés, out of date stereotypes, painfully ineffective attempts to build suspense, bloodless killings, unsurprising twists and acting performances that are beyond amateurish. Johnathon Schaech is a good and versatile actor, but I haven't seen him star in a good film since "The Doom Generation", and somebody really ought to advise him to put a stop to his frequent collaborations with writer/director J.S. Cardone. Schaech's performance is the only remotely decent aspect about "Prom Night", as he depicts a former teacher with a deadly and permanent obsession for one of his female students. Three years before Mr. Fenton barbarically slaughtered Donna's family and swore to return before he was declared insane and got institutionalized. Now he escaped and heads straight for Donna's hometown, just during a night that should have been one of the greatest nights of her life the Prom! The main problem with "Prom Night" (or at least one of the many) probably lies with the characters. You don't care whether they live or die since they're such fake and cardboard individuals. I mean, come on The jock, the sensitive guy, the competitive bitchy girl, the gym teacher with lesbian tendencies, the obsessive cop, the rookie cop, the good-hearted aunt and uncle and so on. Perhaps if the film were intended as a parody the cast of stereotypes could have worked, but unfortunately everyone involved in the production takes this stinker dead serious. The PG-13 says it all in this case: goody-goody childish garbage without violence, guts or even a minimum of sleaze.

review_title: Run of the mill Slasher flick
review_detailed_main: I am amazed by some of the reviews that are surprised by the idiocy of the characters. Duh!! It's a horror film, Stupidity is glue that holds 90% of Horror movies together. This movie is a perfect example, even the cops are morons. Having said that, there's nothing wrong with this movie, it is your bread and butter horror movie with more than adequate acting and direction. Note to Horror lovers, there is no Gore to be seen.

review_title: Worst thing since Day of the Dead (it's PG13, what do you expect?)

review_detailed_main: A childhood fave!! I love Brittany Snow! It's another mid-2000's cult following movie that was iconic for the time. The movie has excellent actors and an over produced plot. The majority of the movie is expected but portrayed well, especially for the time. The script is pretty okay. The casting is great, costuming is excellent - if you love horror Movies and are a 90s child, you will love this movie. Some parts of the movie can be cheesy at times, And some jump scares are expected also. But, there is just something about this movie that is special and iconic for the time. It could be the fact that Idris Elba or Brittany Snow are part of the project considering the year that this movie came out, or it's just a great "campy" horror movie.

review_title: As bad as horror movies get
review_detailed_main:
There should be no shred of humor in what I am about to say: reading the plot description on Wikipedia will give you more chills than the actual viewing of the film. That's what I couldn't help but ponder halfway through 'Prom Night', a poor excuse for a movie that is supposed to instill fear into the viewer. Instead, it instills boredom, disdain, and sheer anger that time and possibly money were spent watching this garbage.

While the premise of 'Prom Night' is not the formula for a masterpiece, it actually had the potential to be somewhat scary and even a decent movie. A teacher becomes obsessed with a female student, murders her family, gets locked away, and escapes years later to return to terrorize her on her prom night. Unfortunately, the director, screenwriters, and actors appeared to make it their mission to throw away any hope of making something memorable. The killer is not menacing, the scares are poorly built up, and the actors are too bored to put in any effort.

'Prom Night' is, to put it plainly, a mess. It's predictable, implausible, clichéd, and mind-numbingly dumb. This is the horror genre at its worst, and, for that matter, American cinema at its worst.

Where do I even begin with this one. I've decided to watch this movie as a background noise while building some models and I had to stop what I was doing because it was way to "distracting". I am a huge fan of the original I knew from the beginning it was gonna be bad! But to butcher a "remake" this way is even worst. For starters, this PG-13 curse is a "curse" for a reason. I guess teenagers in the early 2000s didn't have veins, because you can't see a single drop of blood for miles and miles (except in one occasion, and even there you can't see much effort). The the "Jump Scares"; ho the stupid and idiotic "jump scares" that end up in "absolutely nothing"!!!!! In the first 20 minutes alone of the movie I counted 4 and all of them useless. In short: No creepy factor, No fear of the unknown, No effective horror, No acting and can please someone tell me how on earth they got Idris Elba, of all people, to say yes to that thing?

If you really want to give a chance to a remake, got for Rob Zombies "Halloween 1 and 2". If not, stay away from this one and find something more original to watch.

review_title: Another Loser from Producer Marc Forby
review_detailed_main:
Who keeps hiring this guy to find and produce movies? I recognized this Marc Forby guy's name from 2 other stinkers he produced. I mean, come-on... At least show a little bit of effort with the production value or something. These movies look like they've been shot using someone's credit card. Who's stealing all the money from the budgets? There's no bignames in it so where is the money going and what the hell is Ming-Na doing in such a P.O.S.!

This movie might be the worst so far. It's so full of cliché's and so horribly produced (i.e. no value) that I couldn't even bare to finish it. Maybe it's my fault for not researching who was involved. But at least I only paid $1.00. Where do I write Mr. Forby to get that buck back?

Another crappy remake/reworking of an '80s horror movie. It's not like the original Prom Night is sacred or anything and it certainly could be improved upon. It was, for the most part, a routine slasher (with decidedly little gore). Yet this piece of crap remake somehow manages to be ten times worse and less original than that movie. Basically it's just another boring 21st century retread of a subgenre that had reached its peak long before this came out. There's the obligatory music video gloss and more pretty young people than you would ever want to see in one place at a time. There isn't a single scare to be had and it's all so tired and predictable, it's pathetic. Sadly, there's also some slumming going on from Ming-Na Wen and Idris Elba. Gotta pay the bills, I guess. My score is low but generous. Avoid this trash.

A murderer has returned to take the life of one person, and he's not afraid to knock-off anyone who gets in his way...

Sound familiar? Yeah it does! As well as that, the original Prom Night starred Jamie Lee Curtis who was in Halloween. At least the original had a better story. They shouldn't of made this. It's not just getting in the way of the Scream Queen, but the movie is just downright horrible. I was so excited to go see this, but no. This movie sucked so hard. The acting is bad, the story is bad, the killing scenes are ANYTHING BUT BRUTAL which the original had and it COMPLETELY ALIENATES the original! Brittany Snow should of stuck to John Tucker. I pray they this doesn't spawn ANY sequels.

1/10

review_title: Not as scary as the original
review_detailed_main: I remember the 1980 version of "Prom Night", and it was straight up horror. This version has more comedy than horror. After a date with a friend, her family was slain by a former teacher. Now in her senior year, this survivor gets to go to the prom. Living with her aunt and uncle, she has all the support, including her boyfriend. However, the former teacher who killed her family escaped from prison to stalk her and her friends. So what happened next? The cop(Idris Alba) who was very tenacious on stopping the maniac. To me, this remake is one of the silliest for me. When one of the friends tells the other about her "killer cramps". Who wants to hear about PMS? To me, this remake was too out there. There is still a scare factor out there, just there were too many puns for me to handle. 2 out of 5 stars

review_title: I would want to be killed if I were in this movie!
No suspense, no plot twist, no horror
Prom Night everything is all right
